title: Argentine president Fernández to send bill legalising abortion to National Congress within 10 days
content:
**Argentina's President to Propose Bill Legalizing Abortion within Ten Days**

On Sunday, the President of Argentina announced plans to submit a bill to Congress within the next ten days aimed at legalizing abortion. He emphasized that this issue is fundamentally a "matter of public health."

“In the next 10 days, I will present a bill for the voluntary interruption of pregnancy that legalizes abortion during the initial stages of pregnancy, allowing women to access the healthcare system when they decide to terminate their pregnancy,” President Fernández stated. Thousands gathered outside the National Congress, voicing their support for the legalization of abortion.

Currently, abortion is illegal in this predominantly Catholic nation, permitted only in cases of rape or when the pregnancy poses a risk to the woman's health. Fernández pointed out that the existing law has “condemned many women, often those with limited resources, to resort to unsafe abortive practices in secrecy, endangering their health and lives.”

Government estimates suggest that approximately 350,000 illegal abortions occur annually in Argentina. Since 1921, illegal abortion has been classified as a crime punishable by imprisonment. "A state that is present must protect all citizens, especially women," Fernández added.

Following the announcement, Mariela Belski, director of Amnesty International Argentina, remarked that the president had "heard the calls from women, adolescents, and girls."

However, the proposed legislation has faced criticism from Monsignor Jorge Eduardo Scheinig, who described it as a promotion of a "culture of death." He called for prayers that in Argentina, the value of life prevails over death.

Uruguay, Guyana, and Cuba are the only other Latin American countries where early abortion is legally permitted. In 2018, the Argentine Congress approved a similar bill, but it was ultimately rejected by the Senate.

**Legislative Proposal to Legalize Abortion to be Presented to Argentina's National Congress**
question:
What was the purpose of the bill announced by President Fernández of Argentina?  

A) To ban all forms of abortion in the country  
B) To legalize abortion at the initial time of pregnancy  
C) To restrict abortion to cases of rape only  
D) To increase penalties for illegal abortion

title: Police shoot man dead after 'terrorist-related' knife attack in London
content:
A 20-year-old man, Sudesh Amman, stabbed three people in Streatham, South London, on Sunday afternoon in what police have declared a terrorist-related attack.  Amman, who was under police surveillance following his release from prison a week earlier,  entered a shop, grabbed a large knife, and ran outside, stabbing a man and two women.  Plainclothes counter-terrorism officers, already monitoring him, gave chase and shot him dead outside a shop at approximately 2 PM local time.

One eyewitness described seeing Amman, wearing a fake suicide vest and carrying a machete, being pursued by an officer before being shot.  The eyewitness reported hearing approximately three gunshots.  One male victim was initially listed in critical condition, while one woman sustained minor injuries from shattered glass following the police shooting.  The other woman's injuries were described as not life-threatening.

Amman had been imprisoned since 2018 for 13 terror offenses, serving half his sentence. Police described him as "knife-obsessed," noting he sent his girlfriend videos of beheadings and extremist messages, urging her to kill her non-Muslim parents.  He also outlined his plans for attacks on tourists, police, and soldiers in a message to his girlfriend.  A bomb-making guidebook, a black flag, and an air gun were later recovered from his home.  A notepad containing his "life goals," prioritizing martyrdom and reaching "Jannah" (the afterlife), was also found.

Metropolitan Police Counter Terrorism Command head Alexis Boon stated that while the circumstances of Amman's radicalization remain unclear, his messages indicated a process spanning at least a year.  Boon emphasized the need for vigilance and reporting of radicalization signs.

London Mayor Sadiq Khan thanked the emergency services for their swift response, asserting London's determination to resist terrorism. Prime Minister Boris Johnson similarly expressed his gratitude to emergency services and offered condolences to the injured.
question:
What was the name of the attacker involved in the knife attack in Streatham, London?  

A) Sudesh Amman  
B) Boris Johnson  
C) Sadiq Khan  
D) Alexis Boon

title: SARS-CoV-2 surpasses one million infections worldwide
content:
On Thursday, global cases of SARS-CoV-2 surpassed one million, according to data released by health authorities. The virus, which causes the disease COVID-19, has been linked to at least 52,000 deaths worldwide.

This milestone coincided with Malawi reporting its first cases of the virus and Zambia confirming its first death attributed to COVID-19. North Korea claimed to remain one of the few countries without confirmed coronavirus cases as of Thursday.

As of now, the World Health Organization reported 1,051,635 confirmed cases globally, with 79,332 cases logged in the 24 hours leading up to 10 a.m. (0800 GMT) on April 4. In the United States, over 244,000 cases have been recorded, resulting in at least 5,900 fatalities. CBS News, using data from Johns Hopkins University, reported more than 1,000 deaths in the US on Wednesday due to the virus.

In response to the pandemic, many countries are implementing stricter measures to curb its spread. The mayor of Moscow announced an extension of the city's lockdown until May 1. In a national address, President Vladimir Putin assured that Russians would continue to receive pay without needing to work until April 30. Meanwhile, Portugal’s parliament voted to extend the national state of emergency by an additional 15 days, passing with 215 votes in favor, ten abstentions, and a single opposing vote. In Saudi Arabia, curfews in the holy cities of Mecca and Medina have been extended to cover entire days, a change from the previous schedule of 3 p.m. to 6 a.m. Thailand plans to implement a curfew from 10 p.m. to 4 a.m., while Ohio's Governor Mike DeWine announced the state's stay-at-home order has been extended until May 1.
question:
What milestone regarding COVID-19 was reached on Thursday according to the reported data?

A) 1 million confirmed cases  
B) 52 thousand deaths  
C) 244 thousand US cases  
D) 1 thousand US deaths

title: Samoan government ends state of emergency over measles outbreak
content:
**State of Emergency Lifted in Samoa Following Measles Outbreak**

On Sunday, Samoa officially ended the state of emergency that had been in place since November 15 due to a measles outbreak. The decision to lift the emergency was unanimously voted on by officials on Saturday afternoon and was announced by the National Emergency Operation Centre (NEOC) that evening. NEOC reported a 95% immunization rate as of December 24, with the final measles-related death occurring on December 26.

With the state of emergency lifted, restrictions on public gatherings and travel are being removed, and schools will reopen. The Health Emergency Operation Centre will now take over relief efforts that were previously managed by the NEOC. In addition, the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs have been tasked with developing a recovery plan for cabinet consideration within two weeks.

As of Sunday, the Disease Surveillance Team reported a total of 5,667 measles cases during the outbreak. Of these, 1,846 individuals were hospitalized, with 1,720 discharged, while 81 tragically lost their lives. According to the National Measles Response and Recovery Appeal on December 6, children under five years old were found to be at the highest risk of mortality, largely due to a lag in vaccinations within that age group.

Tupua Tamasese Meaole Hospital resumed normal operations on Sunday, joining Faleolo District Hospital and Leulumoega District Hospital, which returned to regular services on Friday. During the outbreak's peak, Tupua Tamasese Meaole's Acute Primary Care Clinic and Leulumoega District Hospital were converted into measles wards, while Leulumoega was designated to treat patients without measles, allowing for better quarantine measures. The Australian medical mission's fifth rotation will remain in Samoan territory until January 4 to assist with the transition. As of Sunday, teams had begun dismantling the tents set up to accommodate the high volume of patient admissions.

Originally set to end on December 15, the state of emergency was extended by two weeks on December 14 to continue the immunization campaign, with the Prime Minister urging for a goal of 100% vaccination coverage. At that time, the immunization rate had reached 92%, which has since increased to 95% according to NEOC data. Aid organizations have indicated that high vaccination rates are crucial to preventing further outbreaks, as those who are infected are less likely to come into contact with unvaccinated individuals.

UNICEF reported delivering over 105,000 vaccine doses to Samoa by November 22, with a national vaccination campaign launching on November 20. The government mandated free vaccinations for children aged six months to 19 years and women aged 20 to 35. On December 5 and 6, public services were temporarily halted to facilitate a nationwide door-to-door immunization effort, involving 128 vaccination teams.

To contain the disease's spread, the government had previously restricted inter-island travel for individuals under 19, canceled schools, and advised residents to avoid public gatherings and medical facilities unless necessary. Unvaccinated pregnant women were also barred from attending their workplaces.

The outbreak was first confirmed on October 16, after the Victorian Infectious Disease Reference Laboratory in Melbourne identified measles in 7 out of 20 suspected cases. 

In 2019, the Pacific region saw several measles outbreaks, including those in the Philippines, Tonga, Fiji, and American Samoa. The D8 strain, responsible for the outbreak, was identified in Samoa and Fiji. New Zealand acts as a travel hub for smaller Pacific nations. The World Health Organization reported approximately 10 million measles cases and 140,000 related deaths globally in 2018.
question:
What was the immunization rate reported by the National Emergency Operation Centre (NEOC) in Samoa as of December 24 following the measles outbreak?  

A) 81%  
B) 92%  
C) 95%  
D) 100%

title: Joe Biden wins 2020 South Carolina US Democratic presidential primary
content:
On Saturday, former Vice President Joe Biden secured victory in the Democratic Party's South Carolina primary. This primary is a key part of the Democratic Party's process for selecting its nominee for the 2020 United States presidential election.

Biden received approximately 48% of the vote, earning 39 out of South Carolina's 54 delegates, bringing his total to 54 delegates. Senator Bernie Sanders from Vermont finished in second place with around 20% of the vote, garnering 15 delegates for a cumulative total of 60. Coming in third was former Mayor Pete Buttigieg, who received roughly 11% of the votes.

The South Carolina primary marked the fourth stage in the Democratic Party's primary election cycle. The initial caucuses took place in Iowa on February 3, followed by the New Hampshire primary on February 11, and Nevada's caucuses on February 22.

After the South Carolina primary, the delegate standings revealed Bernie Sanders in the lead with 60 delegates, followed closely by Biden with 54. Buttigieg held third place with 26 delegates earned across Iowa, New Hampshire, and Nevada. Meanwhile, Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts had accumulated 8 delegates, and Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota had 7. A total of 1,991 delegates are required to secure the party's nomination.

In the aftermath of the primary, billionaire Tom Steyer announced his withdrawal from the presidential race. He was soon followed by Buttigieg, who also dropped out. Klobuchar's campaign indicated that she would be ending her presidential bid today.

According to the National Conference of State Legislatures, the next set of primary elections for both the Democratic and Republican parties is scheduled for tomorrow, with over a dozen states participating. This day, commonly referred to as "Super Tuesday," will see the Democratic Party hold elections in 14 states and the territory of American Samoa, representing 1,357 delegates. The states participating in the elections include Alabama, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Maine, Massachusetts, Minnesota, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Vermont, and Virginia.
question:
Who won the Democratic Party's primary election in South Carolina for the 2020 United States presidential election?  

A) Bernie Sanders  
B) Elizabeth Warren  
C) Joe Biden  
D) Amy Klobuchar

title: United States military kills Qasem Soleimani
content:
On Thursday, U.S. military forces conducted an airstrike that resulted in the death of Qasem Soleimani, the head of Iran's Quds Force, which is part of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC). The U.S. government characterized the strike as a defensive measure, citing the December 31 attack on the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad as an incident in which Soleimani was implicated.

The airstrike took place near Baghdad International Airport as Soleimani arrived by plane. He was greeted by Abu Mahdi al-Muhandis, the deputy commander of the Iran-backed Popular Mobilization Forces (PMF), who was also killed in the attack. Other casualties included a high-ranking Iraqi official and Mohammed Reda, an airport protocol officer. The Daily Telegraph reported that the airstrike was executed using three rockets launched from helicopters, according to local paramilitary sources.

In a statement following the airstrike, the U.S. justified its actions, which were authorized by President Donald Trump, as necessary for the protection of U.S. personnel overseas. The statement emphasized that Soleimani was actively planning attacks against American diplomats and service members in Iraq and the broader region, highlighting his responsibility for the deaths of numerous U.S. and coalition personnel. The statement further asserted that the strike was aimed at deterring future Iranian aggression and reaffirmed the U.S. commitment to safeguard its people and interests globally.

The airstrike came in response to a series of rocket attacks on the U.S. Embassy in Iraq, carried out by groups connected to the PMF. Ahmed al-Assadi, a spokesman for the PMF, accused both Israel and the United States of being behind the attack, although no evidence of Israeli involvement has been presented as of January 3.

The IRGC announced that Soleimani was "martyred" in the airstrike. Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei declared three days of public mourning, praising Soleimani's dedication to his cause and vowing vengeance for his death, noting him as a symbol of resistance.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu supported the airstrike, calling Trump's decision "swift, forceful, and decisive."

In the aftermath of the strike, the U.S. Embassy in Iraq suspended its operations and advised American citizens to leave the country immediately, urging them to avoid the embassy and seek travel documents from the consulate in another location.

Iraqi acting Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi condemned the airstrike, labeling it "aggression against Iraq" and a violation of the sovereignty of the state and its people.

Soleimani had been designated a terrorist by the U.S. government in 2007, with subsequent sanctions imposed in 2011 related to a plot to assassinate the Saudi Arabian ambassador to the U.S. Last April, the U.S. labeled the IRGC as a terrorist organization, and individual sanctions were also applied against al-Muhandis.
question:
What was the reason given by the United States for the airstrike that killed Qasem Soleimani?

A) It was a retaliatory measure for past attacks  
B) It was deemed a necessary action to protect U.S. personnel abroad  
C) It was in response to a request from the Iraqi government  
D) It was part of a broader military strategy against Iran

title: Iranian government official Mohammad Mir-Mohammadi dies of COVID-19
content:
A council member in Iran, Mir-Mohammadi, has died from COVID-19, the government announced yesterday. He was 71 years old and passed away at Masih-e-Daneshavari Hospital in Tehran.

Mir-Mohammadi had been serving as an advisor to Iran's Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei since 2017. Previously, he represented Iran in the Council of Experts.

Just a few days prior to his death, Mir-Mohammadi's mother also succumbed to COVID-19. She was the sister of a prominent figure in Iranian politics. Several other Iranian officials, including Deputy Health Minister Iraj Harirchi and the Vice President for Women and Family Affairs, have tested positive for the virus.

The Speaker of Parliament extended his condolences via social media.

Ali Reza Raisi, spokesman for the Health Ministry, reported, "Our latest numbers show 523 new infections and 12 additional deaths, bringing the total to 1,501 confirmed cases and 66 fatalities." According to the Johns Hopkins Center for Systems Science and Engineering, 291 patients in Iran have recovered from the virus as of late today.

title: Philippines' largest television network shut down by government
content:
The Philippine government issued a cease and desist order yesterday, following the expiration of the legislative franchise for the broadcast corporation ABS-CBN, which led to the network shutting down its operations. Later that evening, the network signed off and went off-air. This marks the first government-mandated shutdown of the network since the imposition of martial law by former President Ferdinand Marcos in 1972.

According to Republic Act No. 3846, known as the "Radio Control Law," operating a radio broadcasting station requires a franchise obtained from the Congress of the Philippines. With the expiration of ABS-CBN's franchise, Republic Act No. 7966, on Monday, the company no longer had the legal authority to broadcast its programs. The National Telecommunications Commission (NTC) issued the cease and desist order in response, which the network complied with that night.

ABS-CBN had sought to renew its franchise as early as July 2019, but all eleven legislative bills submitted for this purpose have remained stalled. The franchise expired on the same day Congress reconvened after its break, which began on March 13. While the NTC has the discretion to grant provisional licenses pending legislative decisions, it declined to provide such a license to ABS-CBN. Critics have condemned the NTC's action, calling it a "grave abuse of governmental power" and contrary to the law.

ABS-CBN Corporation is the largest radio and television broadcasting company in the Philippines, operating over 42 television stations, 10 digital channels, and 23 radio stations (18 FM and 5 AM). The network has been in operation for more than 65 years. President Rodrigo Duterte previously threatened the network's franchise renewal after it did not air some of his campaign commercials, which the network attributed to a lack of available airtime. Solicitor General Jose Calida filed a petition against the network in February, alleging franchise violations, yet a subsequent Senate hearing did not find sufficient evidence of any legal breaches. ABS-CBN CEO Carlo Katigbak offered refunds for Duterte's unaired political ads, although some were declined by his campaign. Katigbak also apologized to Duterte during the Senate hearing, a gesture that was acknowledged by the president through his spokesperson, Harry Roque.

Despite the shutdown of its main broadcasting operations, ABS-CBN’s news channel remains on air, as the network maintains that the cease and desist order does not affect its news channel's franchise.
question:
What is the main reason for the cease and desist order issued to ABS-CBN by the Philippine government?

A) The network's news channel was found to be violating laws  
B) The network's legislative franchise expired  
C) The network refused to air political ads  
D) The network was accused of swindling

title: Bloomberg, Warren end US presidential campaigns following Super Tuesday
content:
On Tuesday, the Democratic Party of the United States held primary elections in fourteen states and caucuses in American Samoa, marking an important event known as "Super Tuesday" in the context of presidential elections. Following this pivotal day, two candidates—Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg—announced the suspension of their campaigns.

The term "Super Tuesday" refers to the significant number of primaries and caucuses occurring simultaneously. The states participating in this year's elections were Alabama, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Maine, Massachusetts, Minnesota, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Vermont, and Virginia. Along with American Samoa, these contests included a total of 1,357 delegates up for grabs at the Democratic National Convention.

To secure the Democratic Party's nomination for the 2020 presidential election, a candidate must gather at least 1,991 delegates, and the primaries serve as one method for selecting the nominee.

Super Tuesday marked the fifth phase in the Democratic primary election cycle. The series began with caucuses in Iowa on February 3, followed by the New Hampshire primary on February 11, Nevada’s caucuses on February 22, and South Carolina's primary on the Saturday preceding Super Tuesday.

Entering Super Tuesday, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont led with 60 pledged delegates, followed closely by former Vice President Joe Biden with 54 delegates. Senator Warren had accrued eight delegates, while Pete Buttigieg, former Mayor of South Bend, Indiana, and Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota had also secured delegates in earlier contests before ending their campaigns.

On Super Tuesday itself, Sanders achieved a plurality in his home state of Vermont and three additional states—Colorado, Utah, and California—as projected by CNN. Meanwhile, Biden emerged as the frontrunner in ten states, including Virginia, North Carolina, Alabama, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Minnesota, Arkansas, Massachusetts, Texas, and Maine.

Bloomberg claimed victory in the caucus for American Samoa, marking his first win of the campaign. He had opted to forgo earlier primaries and instead concentrated on Super Tuesday, securing five of the territory's six delegates, alongside three delegates in Colorado and one in Arkansas. U.S. Representative Tulsi Gabbard from Hawaii earned the remaining delegate from American Samoa, her first of the season.

On the same day he withdrew from the race, Bloomberg endorsed his rival, Joe Biden. He stated, "Three months ago, I entered the race for President to defeat Donald Trump. Today, I am leaving the race for the same reason: to defeat Donald Trump—because it is clear to me that staying in would make achieving that goal more difficult... It is clear that candidate is my friend and a great American, Joe Biden... Today I am glad to endorse him—and I will work to make him the next President of the United States."

Warren, who lost her home state of Massachusetts and finished third—behind Biden and Sanders—suspended her campaign without winning any primaries or caucuses. Reports indicated that before suspending her campaign, Klobuchar was leading the polls in Minnesota, her home state.

The Democratic Party allocates delegates proportionally based on candidates' performance, requiring candidates to receive at least 15% of the vote to qualify for delegate allocation from a state, territory, or district.

Looking ahead, the Democratic Party's primary season will continue on March 10, featuring elections in Idaho, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, North Dakota, and Washington.
question:
What was the total number of delegates represented by the contests held on Super Tuesday, including American Samoa?  

A) 1,540  
B) 1,357  
C) 1,991  
D) 1,600

title: Indian Railway: all-women crew steers Tippu Express ahead of International Women's Day
content:
Yesterday, an all-women crew successfully operated the Mysuru–Bengaluru train in the Indian state of Karnataka, an initiative launched by state-run Indian Railways in celebration of International Women's Day and to promote gender equality in the workplace.

B. Shiva Parvathi served as the loco pilot, while 22-year-old Rangoli Patil took on the role of loco co-pilot. The train departed from the railway station at 6:00 AM, covering a distance of 139 kilometers to reach its destination. It was adorned with banners celebrating "International Women's Day."

In an interview with the press, B. Shiva Parvathi expressed her pride, stating, "It is a proud moment for me to be steering this train today alongside Loco Pilot Rangoli and our all-women staff." Mysore Divisional Railway Manager Aparna Garg highlighted that currently only 10% of the workforce is female, translating to about 650 women among the employees.

The Mysore district operates under the South Western Railway (SWR) division of Indian Railways. The celebrations for Women's Day commenced on March 1st and are set to continue until March 8th, with various activities planned, including health check-ups, yoga sessions, sports competitions, and trekking, as reported by local news outlets.

Aparna Garg emphasized the theme, "Equal for All," as a commitment by the Railways to bolster women's representation in the workforce and empower them. She remarked, "Women today are equally capable as men in any field. I hope initiatives like this inspire more women to pursue careers in their areas of interest," as shared with Star of Mysore.

Who served as the loco pilot for the train run by the all-women crew in Karnataka ahead of International Women's Day?  

A) Rangoli Patil  
B) Aparna Garg  
C) B Shiva Parvathi  
D) Women employees of Indian Railways

title: US state of Wisconsin holds 2020 election amidst COVID-19 concerns
content:
**Wisconsin Holds Elections Amid Court Battle and Health Concerns**

Today, Wisconsin held elections following a contentious court battle over efforts to delay or extend voting due to health concerns stemming from the spread of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19.

The elections included primary contests for both the Democratic and Republican parties, as well as a general election to fill a seat in the state legislature. Primary elections, along with caucuses, are key processes that both parties use to select their nominees for the 2020 United States presidential election. Notably, all other U.S. states scheduled to hold elections in April have either postponed them or switched to entirely mail-in voting.

To secure the Democratic Party’s nomination, candidates must accumulate at least 1,991 delegates. Delegates are awarded proportionally based on a candidate's performance, with a requirement of at least 15% of the vote to qualify for delegates from a state, territory, or district. Wisconsin's primary offers 84 delegates. As of now, former Vice President Joe Biden has garnered 1,217 pledged delegates, while Senator Bernie Sanders has accumulated 914.

In a last-minute decision, Wisconsin Governor Tony Evers signed an executive order yesterday to delay the election until June, citing health risks associated with the COVID-19 pandemic. This move followed a ruling by U.S. District Judge William Conley, which allowed absentee ballots to be accepted until April 13, with votes not being counted until then.

Evers’ decision faced legal challenges, with the court ruling that he lacked the authority to unilaterally reschedule the election. The U.S. Supreme Court later rejected Conley’s extension of absentee voting rights as well. However, a portion of the court ruling that was upheld stated that ballots would not be counted until 4 p.m. on April 13.

The upcoming election saw a number of poll workers resigning due to health concerns, prompting the state to rely on the National Guard to staff polling locations. In Milwaukee, the number of polling stations was drastically reduced from 180 to just 5, resulting in long lines that stretched for multiple blocks.

Before the deadline last week, over 1 million individuals requested absentee ballots for mail-in voting. According to reports, as of yesterday morning, over 500,000 ballots had yet to be returned, and more than 11,000 absentee ballots had not yet been sent out.
question:
What was the result of the Wisconsin elections held today amidst the COVID-19 pandemic?  

A) The elections were successfully conducted without any issues.  
B) The elections were delayed by the governor until June.  
C) Wisconsin switched to only mail-in voting for the elections.  
D) The United States Supreme Court ruled that absentee ballots could be counted until April 13.

title: Wikinews discusses International Women's Day celebration with Mysore Divisional Railway Manager
content:
**Wikinews Interviews Mysore Divisional Railway Manager on International Women’s Day Celebration**

This Thursday, an all-women crew successfully operated the Mysore-Bangalore train in Karnataka, India, as part of a state-run Indian Railways initiative to promote gender equality in the workplace ahead of International Women’s Day, observed on March 8. Aparna Garg, the Divisional Railway Manager (DRM) for Mysore Division, spoke with Wikinews about this significant event.

---

**Wikinews:** Good afternoon, ma'am. Thank you for joining us today. Congratulations to the Mysuru Division for having an all-women crew operate the Tippu Express from Mysore to Bangalore. How many individuals were part of this crew?

**Aparna Garg:** There were fifteen crew members in total. While a train crew typically consists of just the locomotive pilot and the guard, our team included ticket inspectors, escort staff, and Railway Police Force personnel, so the overall crew included around fifteen people.

**Wikinews:** How unusual is it to have an all-women crew running a train?

**Aparna Garg:** It is quite rare. We are actually conducting a ten-day campaign for International Women’s Day, with a new activity each day, and this initiative is part of that campaign.

**Wikinews:** Has there ever been an all-women crew in the Southern Western Railway before this?

**Aparna Garg:** Not really, although it has happened in other divisions. Mysore may be the first within our division.

**Wikinews:** Are you aware of any similar events in other regional divisions?

**Aparna Garg:** I believe Bangalore has engaged in similar initiatives, but regarding an all-female crew, there have been accomplishments on a national level.

**Wikinews:** Can you elaborate on this event and when it was planned?

**Aparna Garg:** As I mentioned, we have a ten-day campaign themed "Each for Equal." This theme emphasizes that everyone can contribute to creating a gender-equal world, and we aim to highlight the various roles women hold in male-dominated areas, including railway positions such as locomotive pilots and track patrols.

**Wikinews:** Was this campaign initiated by the Southern Western Railway or Indian Railways more broadly?

**Aparna Garg:** This initiative specifically came from the Mysore Division, which is part of South Western Railway.

**Wikinews:** What other activities has Indian Railways planned for International Women’s Day?

**Aparna Garg:** Indian Railways has outlined various initiatives, focusing on "Each for Equal." From March 1 to March 10, we are organizing talks, lectures, and other activities aimed at highlighting the steps taken to enhance women's empowerment across all sectors. This includes social media posts and creating videos that specifically feature women in our workforce. 

In Mysore division, we’ve conducted medical screenings for cervical cancer, providing access to healthcare for both office staff and contract cleaners, who often lack good health facilities. Today, we organized a trekking event for some of our female employees, and we have more activities planned for the upcoming days.

**Wikinews:** How does this year’s celebration differ from last year's?

**Aparna Garg:** Last year’s focus was mainly on March 8 alone. This year, by spreading the celebration over ten days, we aim to deepen our impact and encourage greater participation.

**Wikinews:** What activities are planned during this celebration period?

**Aparna Garg:** Our goal is to encourage women employees to engage in activities outside of their routine work, allowing them to showcase their talents. For instance, we've organized events like "pick-and-speak" that highlight the skills of our female staff, including those in lower-level positions. Furthermore, our focus is also on ensuring enhanced security for women passengers.

**Wikinews:** Would you consider this event a success so far?

**Aparna Garg:** Yes, we’ve made significant progress.

**Wikinews:** What challenges do women face while working for Indian Railways?

**Aparna Garg:** The challenges for women mirror those in broader society. Achieving workplace success often requires women to exert more effort than their male counterparts, and recognition can come late. Women often juggle multiple responsibilities, including household duties, and yet remain dedicated and sincere in their work.

**Wikinews:** What solutions do you recommend for these challenges?

**Aparna Garg:** Events like Women’s Day help bring focus to these issues, but broader societal change is needed. We must work to shift mindsets, beginning in the home. It’s crucial to sensitize male colleagues and family members to support women’s contributions.

**Wikinews:** What is the current gender distribution in the Mysore Division?

**Aparna Garg:** Currently, women represent about ten percent of our total workforce of approximately 6,900 employees, which equates to around 650 women.

**Wikinews:** Are you satisfied with this percentage?

**Aparna Garg:** It’s a start, but I believe that individuals should choose their careers based on personal interest. This is not just about gender but about capabilities.

**Wikinews:** Has the number of women employees increased over recent years?

**Aparna Garg:** Yes, it has increased from about seven or eight percent to the current ten percent. We are seeing more women entering technical roles that were previously male-dominated, such as locomotive pilots and station masters.

**Wikinews:** What measures is Indian Railways taking to further improve gender representation?

**Aparna Garg:** While there isn’t specific gender-based reservation, Indian Railways has shown willingness to promote gender diversity. Although the number of women in managerial roles was low historically, it is now steadily increasing.

**Wikinews:** Please share your responsibilities as the Mysore Divisional Railway Manager.

**Aparna Garg:** In my role, I oversee operations and train schedules across a route of approximately 1,300 kilometers. I lead a team of thirty officers and manage 6,900 staff members, ensuring the efficient functioning of our division.

**Wikinews:** How long have you been in this position?

**Aparna Garg:** I’ll be completing two years in this role come April.

**Wikinews:** Can you highlight some of your career achievements?

**Aparna Garg:** Initially passing civil services was a pivotal moment for me. My career has included various challenging projects, including developing software systems for project management, and managing extensive renovations at our railway stations while maintaining historical integrity. Importantly, I spearheaded initiatives to enhance our railway museum and improve environmental health around our facilities.

**Wikinews:** How has the Mysore Division approached health safety in light of the coronavirus pandemic?

**Aparna Garg:** We closely collaborate with health officials to ensure we are prepared. We have isolation wards to manage any cases, and we provide public announcements regarding safety measures. We also distribute masks to our frontline staff who interact daily with the public.

**Wikinews:** Thank you very much for your time today.

title: Iraqi Parliament votes for expulsion of United States troops
content:
Yesterday, the Iraqi Parliament cast a vote on a resolution calling for the expulsion of United States troops from the country. This decision came in the wake of a US airstrike last week that killed Iranian General Qasem Soleimani.

The vote, which is non-binding, was boycotted by both Kurdish and Sunni Members of Parliament and is pending approval from the Iraqi government. According to NPR, the caretaker Prime Minister has recommended the withdrawal of US troops from Iraq.

As of yesterday, the United States had not announced any plans to withdraw its troops, who are part of an international coalition aimed at combating the Islamic State (ISIS). Following the parliamentary vote, State Department spokesperson Morgan Ortagus expressed disappointment at the decision, stating, "While we await further clarification on the legal nature and impact of today’s resolution, we strongly urge Iraqi leaders to reconsider the importance of the ongoing economic and security relationship between our two countries and the continued presence of the Global Coalition to Defeat ISIS."

The coalition was formed to assist Iraq in battling ISIS after the group took control of roughly a third of the country. Although the Iraqi government has since declared victory over ISIS, US troops remain stationed in Iraq to prevent the group's resurgence.

The airstrike that killed Soleimani occurred in Iraq, and Iraqi officials condemned it as "a serious violation of Iraqi sovereignty."
question:
What was the primary reason for the Iraqi Parliament's vote to expel United States troops from the country?  

A) Ongoing military operations against ISIS  
B) The killing of Qasem Soleimani by a US airstrike

title: Bangladesh reports five new deaths due to COVID-19, a daily highest
content:
**Bangladesh Reports Highest Daily COVID-19 Fatalities**

Yesterday, Bangladesh confirmed five new COVID-19-related deaths, marking the highest daily death toll since the outbreak began. As of the latest update from the Institute of Epidemiology, Disease Control and Research (IEDCR), the country has recorded 114 active cases and 33 recovered cases, with a total of 17 fatalities to date.

The victims' age distribution included two individuals over 60 years old, two between the ages of 51 and 60, and one aged 41-50. Two of the deceased resided in Dhaka. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared COVID-19 a pandemic on March 11.

A hospital official informed Anadolu Agency that one of the deceased, Jalal Saifur Rahman, was a director at the Bengali Anti-Corruption Commission and was receiving treatment at Kuwait Maitree Hospital.

In light of the rising cases, Bangladeshi Road Transport and Bridges Minister Obaidul Quader announced in a Saturday video address that the public transport shutdown will be extended until this coming Saturday. The shutdown, which began on March 26, had originally been slated to end on April 4. However, transport of essential goods, including medical supplies, fuel, and food, will continue.

The first cases of COVID-19 in Bangladesh were reported on March 8, involving two individuals who had returned from Italy and the wife of one of them. By March 19, all three had recovered from the virus.

title: Fire erupts in parking structure at Sola Airport, Norway
content:
At approximately 3:30 PM local time on Tuesday, a fire broke out in a parking structure at Stavanger Airport in Norway. The parking facility, which accommodates over 3,000 vehicles, was reported to be more than 50% full at the time of the incident. The airport was quickly closed to air traffic in response to the situation.

Initial reports indicated that the fire originated from an electric vehicle. However, a news broadcaster later clarified that it started from a recalled 2005 model involved in a similar incident in Cork, Ireland, last August, which damaged around 60 vehicles. Authorities have since questioned the car's owner.

The fire generated thick smoke, raising concerns about the potential for the building to collapse. Nils-Erik Haagenrud from Fire and Rescue confirmed that no personnel would be sent into the structure on Tuesday evening. Rogaland Fire and Rescue requested assistance and equipment from neighboring fire departments. Both the airport and a nearby hotel were evacuated, and local police urged residents in the vicinity to stay indoors and secure all windows and exterior vents. By Tuesday evening, the intensity of the fire had decreased, and the order for a fire-extinguishing robot from Oslo Fire and Rescue was subsequently canceled.

The airport closure led to Norwegian Prime Minister Erna Solberg being stranded after a visit. She posted on Twitter seeking recommendations for places to eat during a seven-hour drive back to Oslo.

As of Wednesday, reports indicated that an estimated 200 to 300 vehicles were damaged or destroyed, but there were no reported injuries.

By around 10:00 PM local time on Tuesday, firefighters brought the flames under control. Local crews planned to continue monitoring the situation to prevent further damage and discovered that the parking structure had been constructed without sprinklers. Stavanger Airport is expected to reopen on Wednesday morning, although full service recovery may take additional time. Affected travelers have been advised to contact their airlines for rebooking options.

What was the cause of the fire that led to the closure of the airport in Norway?

A) A natural gas leak  
B) A recalled 2005 electric vehicle  
C) An arson incident  
D) A malfunctioning fuel tank

title: Bernie Sanders ends 2020 US presidential bid
content:
On Wednesday, Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders announced the end of his campaign for the Democratic Party's nomination in the 2020 presidential election. 

In a live stream to his supporters, Sanders explained his decision, highlighting that he had secured approximately 300 fewer delegates than former Vice President Joe Biden, stating that "the path toward victory is virtually impossible." To clinch the Democratic nomination, a candidate needs at least 1,991 delegates.

He emphasized that while his campaign is concluding, "the struggle for justice continues." In his announcement, he reiterated his commitment to issues such as affordable higher education, healthcare access, and raising the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour.

Sanders’ withdrawal from the race positions Biden as the presumptive nominee for the party. In a subsequent interview on Wednesday, Sanders referred to Biden as a "decent man," but he did not provide a full endorsement at that time. On the Republican side, incumbent President Donald Trump has been the presumptive nominee since March.

Sanders previously ran for the Democratic nomination in the 2016 election but lost to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.

title: Greek prime minister reaffirms EastMed pipeline project is open for other countries to join
content:
**Greek Prime Minister Confirms Commitment to EastMed Pipeline amid Regional Tensions**

On Tuesday, Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis reaffirmed the EastMed pipeline project, which aims to connect Eastern Mediterranean gas fields to the European mainland, despite navigating through contested waters.

During a live-streamed presentation at a U.S. think tank in Washington, Mitsotakis emphasized that the EastMed initiative, which currently includes Greece, Cyprus, and Israel, is open to additional countries joining the project. "We don’t seek to exclude anyone from energy cooperation in the Eastern Mediterranean, provided they respect international law," he stated, echoing remarks he made during the January 2 signing ceremony for the EastMed agreement.

Mitsotakis also criticized the recent maritime border agreement between Turkey and Libya, labeling it "null and void" and "geographically ridiculous." He pointed out that the agreement disregards the exclusive economic zones (EEZ) of Greek islands, including Crete, which contradicts established international law. He mentioned that the Greek government has rejected the demarcation, and he noted the possibility of the matter being resolved at The Hague if diplomatic discussions do not succeed. Mitsotakis expressed a desire for open dialogue with Turkey, stating he would be "very, very happy" if Turkey reconsidered its stance.

Later, Mitsotakis met with officials from the International Monetary Fund and President Trump, where he reiterated his condemnation of the Turkey-Libya agreement, highlighting its infringement on Greece’s sovereign rights.

This past Thursday, delegations from Cyprus, Greece, and Israel convened in Athens for their seventh trilateral summit, where they agreed to expedite the construction of the EastMed pipeline by 2025. The summit was attended by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, along with energy ministers from Greece, Cyprus, and Israel. The agreement was formally signed by the energy ministers. A Greek daily reported that Greece and Cyprus must accelerate their efforts to prevent potential Turkish interference with the project.

Earlier on the same day, a Greek gas producer signed a letter of intent to supply two billion cubic meters of gas annually to a Greek gas distributor, while the EastMed pipeline is expected to support a total capacity of 10 billion cubic meters per year. Energean, the gas producer, has committed $1.7 billion to development in the Karish and Tanin fields.

Netanyahu, in forming this political and economic alliance with Greece and Cyprus, expressed hopes that the EastMed pipeline would help elevate their geopolitical status. He urged Italy and Egypt to join the project, inviting any interested parties to participate. In Cyprus, the ruling party celebrated the pipeline project as a significant advancement in national sovereignty, though the main opposition party cautioned that actual construction depends on securing investment from still undecided private investors. Turkish Foreign Ministry spokesperson Hami Aksoy asserted Turkish and Turkish Cypriot rights in the area, suggesting that overlooking these rights could jeopardize the project.

Italy is a proposed endpoint for the pipeline, and the Italian economic development minister expressed support prior to the signing. However, the minister indicated that Italy is pursuing an alternative pipeline route to Greece. The United States has shown support through various initiatives, including the December 20 signing of the Eastern Mediterranean Bill and a quadrilateral meeting held in Washington.

In December, a Turkish official claimed that the operational Trans-Anatolian Natural Gas Pipeline renders the EastMed project unnecessary. Tensions escalated when Turkey and Libya signed a maritime border agreement in November, asserting rights over sections of sea between Crete and Cyprus, causing Greece to expel the Libyan ambassador.

The EUM has partially funded feasibility studies for the EastMed pipeline, which is viewed as a Project of Common Interest (PCI) aimed at enhancing Europe's energy security by reducing reliance on Russian gas and diversifying supplies. 

Prominent energy experts have pointed out the project's geopolitical implications may outweigh its economic viability, given the high estimated costs and fierce competition in the gas market. The pipeline, projected at 2,000 kilometers in length, is intended to connect energy fields with Crete, the Greek mainland, and terminate in Otranto, Italy.

In a related development, during a trilateral meeting in 2016, the concept of an underwater electricity cable connecting the three nations was discussed as an alternative energy export route. This project is expected to be completed by December 2023 and has significant EU backing as a PCI, further aligning regional energy strategies.

A) Legally binding  
B) Constructive and necessary  
C) Null and void  
D) A significant regional collaboration

title: US Supreme Court overturns fraud convictions in Kelly v. United States
content:
Yesterday, the United States Supreme Court overturned the criminal convictions of Bridget Anne Kelly and Bill Baroni, stemming from a 2013 incident that involved alleged politically motivated traffic disruptions at a major bridge connecting New Jersey to Manhattan. Kelly, who served as Deputy Chief of Staff to then-New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, and Baroni, the former Deputy Executive Director of the Port Authority, had previously been convicted of fraud for their roles in the events.

The case was centered around traffic chaos at the George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee, New Jersey. In September 2013, traffic "ground to a halt" for four days, as noted in the Supreme Court's decision. During this time, only one of the twelve access lanes to the bridge was open to commuters, a significant reduction from the three lanes typically reserved for morning rush hour. The public officials responsible for this lane reversal claimed it was for a legitimate traffic study. However, the Supreme Court's ruling indicated that the motive behind their actions was political: to retaliate against the mayor of Fort Lee for his refusal to endorse the Governor’s reelection campaign.

The Supreme Court examined whether Kelly and Baroni's conduct constituted property fraud under federal law. In a unanimous decision, the justices concluded that their actions did not meet the criteria for fraud, leading to the reversal of their convictions and a remand of the case to the Third Circuit Court of Appeals.

In the majority opinion, Justice Elena Kagan stated, "Not every corrupt act by state or local officials is a federal crime. Because the scheme here did not aim to obtain money or property, Baroni and Kelly could not have violated the federal-program fraud or wire fraud laws."
question:
What was the reason the United States Supreme Court overturned the criminal convictions of Bridget Anne Kelly and Bill Baroni?  
  
A) Their actions aimed to obtain money or property.  
B) They were found to be acting in accordance with federal statutes.

title: English mathematician John Horton Conway dies after contracting COVID-19
content:
English mathematician John Conway passed away on Saturday at his New Jersey home, reportedly due to complications from COVID-19. A Princeton University professor noted that Conway developed a fever on Wednesday prior to his death at the age of 82.

Conway is best known for devising the Game of Life, a cellular automaton that consists of a grid of cells that evolve based on specific rules. He also created the surreal number system, which provides a way to express very large integers. Additionally, Conway formulated the theory of knot classification and contributed to various areas in mathematics.

In recognition of his significant contributions to the field, Conway was elected as a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1981 and was admitted to the National Academy of Sciences in 1992. His accolades include the Berwick Prize in 1971, the Pólya Prize in 1987, the Knuth Prize in 1998, and the Royal Society's Sylvester Medal in 2000.

Conway's passing has been met with an outpouring of grief from the academic community. Neuroscientist Sam Wang remembered him as "an incomparable mathematician, a pleasant neighbor, and an excellent coffee acquaintance." US theoretical astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson tweeted that Conway "was a warm and gentle soul." Independent filmmaker and journalist Kevin McCullough, known for his educational YouTube channel, dedicated a podcast episode to honor Conway's legacy.

title: Iranian International Master Dorsa Derakhshani discusses her chess career with Wikinews
content:
### Iranian International Master Dorsa Derakhshani Reflects on Her Chess Journey with Wikinews

In February 2017, the Iranian Chess Federation announced that two teenage chess players, International Master (IM) Dorsa Derakhshani and her younger brother, Borna, had been banned from representing the national team. This decision came despite Dorsa's prior notification to the federation that she no longer wished to play for Iran.

Now 21, Dorsa holds both the IM and Woman Grandmaster (WGM) titles, while Borna currently plays for the UK and also holds the title of IM.

Dorsa's ban stemmed from her decision to compete without a hijab during the 2017 World Youth Chess Championship, where adherence to the hijab as a mandatory dress code is enforced under Islamic law in Iran. Borna's ban occurred after he played against Israeli Grandmaster (GM) at the same tournament. Iran does not recognize the legitimacy of Israel, leading to a historic avoidance by Iranian athletes of competing against Israeli counterparts.

Mehrdad Pahlavanzadeh, president of the Iranian Chess Federation, clarified their decision, linking it to the players’ actions.

Dorsa, who is now studying at Saint Louis University in the United States and playing for the US chess federation, spoke with a Wikinews correspondent about her chess career, life in Iran, the 2017 controversy, and her experiences in St. Louis.

**Early Chess Interest and Background**

Growing up in Tehran, Dorsa was influenced by her father, who played chess in high school before the Islamic Revolution. Despite the ban on public chess games during that time, he played at home, eventually teaching Dorsa the game.

"My dad is a pediatrician and my mom is a psychiatrist. They put a lot of emphasis on education," she recalls. Dorsa excelled academically, completing first grade at just two-and-a-half years old and finishing fourth grade by age four. The lack of available chess tournaments for talented young players was a significant challenge she faced in Iran.

**Training as a Young Chess Prodigy**

Dorsa's competitive spirit motivated her to become the best at chess. She reflects on winning the Girl's Under-8 National Championship as a pivotal moment in her chess career. 

"Chess had a clear category for success. I won my first tournament early on, and it became apparent to me that I was really good at it," she said.

**Challenges Faced in Iran**

Dorsa faced numerous hurdles as a female chess player in Iran, including limited access to tournaments and strict regulations on women's participation. She advocated for female players, compelling her federation to allow her to compete in male tournaments despite initial resistance.

At just eight years old, she sought to participate in competitions beyond the constraints placed on female players. Ultimately, Dorsa made the decision not to represent the Iranian Chess Federation, stating, "It wasn't a good fit."

**Decision to Immigrate and Change Federations**

In 2016, Dorsa informed the Iranian Chess Federation of her choice to switch federations. Following her immigration to Spain, she received scholarship offers from several US colleges, ultimately deciding to move to the United States.

Dorsa emphasized that her decision was not solely about the hijab but about the larger societal view of women in Iran, forcing her to work much harder to gain recognition as an equal player. 

"If I had a better voice and future prospects in Iran, I might have made a different choice,” she remarked.

**Current Life and Future Aspirations**

Now, Dorsa is thriving at Saint Louis University, studying to become a surgeon and playing chess actively. She is involved in the chess community and enjoys a supportive environment at her university. 

"My biggest dream is to break into the top five players in the US and to teach younger players about chess," she stated.

Dorsa also expressed her desire for chess to become more inclusive and for the titles to be restructured to provide a level playing field for all players, regardless of gender.

**Reflections on Identity and Growth**

Reflecting on her journey, Dorsa acknowledges the impact of her experiences in Iran and her ongoing mental adjustment to life in the US.

“I’ve learned to be true to myself. It’s okay not to please everyone,” she concluded.

The challenges Dorsa has faced and her determination to succeed serve as an inspiration to many, highlighting the resilience required to navigate the intersections of culture, identity, and ambition in the world of chess.
question:
What was the reason for Dorsa Derakhshani being banned from representing the Iranian national team in 2017? 

A) She did not win any tournaments  
B) She refused to play against Israeli players  
C) She did not wear a hijab during competition  
D) She wanted to join an international chess federation

title: Cairo summit denounces Turkish-Libyan maritime border agreement
content:
On Wednesday, foreign ministers from several countries convened in Cairo to condemn the recent memoranda of understanding between Turkey and Libya. These agreements, which delineate maritime borders in the Eastern Mediterranean and facilitate Turkish military deployments in Libya, have resulted in overlapping claims of Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZ) and are viewed as a threat to regional stability.

The Egyptian foreign minister was joined by his counterparts from Greece, Cyprus, and France, while Italy participated as an observer. Together, they issued a statement declaring the November 27 maritime border agreement between Turkey and Libya as "null and void," asserting that it infringes upon the sovereign rights of third states, does not align with international law, and lacks any legal validity. They urged Turkey to cease its drilling operations within Cyprus's EEZ and criticized the military cooperation aspect of the agreement in the context of Libya's ongoing civil war, stating it contravenes United Nations Security Council Resolution 2259.

The ministers agreed to future discussions aimed at addressing these geopolitical tensions.

In a subsequent press release, Turkey rejected the summit's conclusions, asserting that the agreements are "legitimate and fully compliant with international law." Turkey invited the involved countries to engage in dialogue, with the exception of Cyprus, which it does not recognize.

During the opening ceremony of a newly launched gas pipeline, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan called for regional cooperation in the Eastern Mediterranean and emphasized Turkey's right to participate in projects based on its extensive coastline. He stated, "No project excluding our country in the Eastern Mediterranean can be implemented in terms of economic, judicial, and diplomatic considerations," and reiterated Turkey's commitment to protecting the interests of both Turkish and Turkish Cypriot communities.

On Tuesday, Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis criticized the border agreement as "null and void" and "geographically absurd," arguing that it disregards the exclusive economic zones of Greek islands, including Crete. He pointed out that the Greek Parliament has not ratified the demarcation and suggested the possibility of arbitration through the International Court of Justice. He identified the border dispute as the key point of contention between Greece and Turkey.

Under the terms of the November 27 agreement, Turkey and Libya established a maritime border line that would classify the waters between Crete and Cyprus as part of Turkey's EEZ. Turkey justifies this claim by citing its extensive coastline and referencing precedents where islands had a limited role in maritime boundary determinations. Greece responded by expelling the Libyan ambassador in protest of the agreement.

The EastMed pipeline project, a collaboration between Israel, Cyprus, and Greece, aims to transport gas from Eastern Mediterranean offshore fields to Europe, traversing waters claimed by Turkey. Both Egypt and Italy, which have their own gas interests, have been invited to partake in the initiative.
question:
What did the assembly of foreign ministers in Cairo denounce regarding the agreement between Turkey and Libya?  

A) Its legitimacy under international law  
B) Its compatibility with the United Nations Security Council resolution 2259  
C) Its designation of maritime borders in the Eastern Mediterranean  
D) Its agreement on economic cooperation

title: World Health Organization declares COVID-19 pandemic
content:
On Wednesday, the World Health Organization (WHO) officially classified the ongoing outbreak of COVID-19, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus, as a pandemic. 

While the term "pandemic" primarily describes the widespread nature of a disease rather than its severity, the WHO emphasized the urgent need for governments to take action. "All countries can still change the course of this pandemic. If countries detect, test, treat, isolate, trace, and mobilize their populations effectively," stated Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the Director-General of the WHO. He also expressed concern about both the rapid spread and the insufficient response: "We are deeply worried by the alarming levels of spread and severity, as well as the alarming levels of inaction."

Dr. Robert Redfield, the former director of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, described the pandemic as "unprecedented." In comments shared with CNN in February, he noted, "Other than influenza, no other respiratory virus has been tracked from emergence to continuous global spread."

Dr. Ghebreyesus echoed similar sentiments, stating, "We have never before seen a pandemic sparked by a coronavirus," and adding, "And we have never before seen a pandemic that can be controlled at the same time."

This designation as a pandemic comes after the WHO declared the outbreak a Public Health Emergency of International Concern in January. Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, cautioned earlier about the situation, saying, "Bottom line, it's going to get worse."

As of Thursday, the Associated Press reported at least 126,000 confirmed cases of COVID-19 globally, resulting in over 4,600 fatalities.

title: British mathematician Richard K. Guy dies at 103
content:
Richard K. Guy, a renowned British mathematician with over 300 published papers across various mathematical disciplines, passed away on Monday at the age of 103.

Prior to his death, Guy was a mathematics professor at the University of Calgary. Although he retired in 1982, he remained actively involved in the Department of Mathematics and Statistics. In October 2016, the university honored him with a celebration for his 100th birthday. He was also one of the original directors of the department.

Throughout his career, Guy was instrumental in identifying a unique pattern known as the "Guy's Conjecture" within the context of a cellular automaton—a discrete model featuring a grid of cells, which was formulated by mathematician John von Neumann around 1970.

From approximately 1948 to 1951, Guy served as the endings editor for the influential journal "The American Mathematical Monthly" and contributed to nearly 200 mathematical studies. He was also a co-inventor of a system for representing chess piece positions.

Richard Guy is survived by his wife, Nancy Louise Thirian, and their three children, including noted computer scientist and mathematician Richard Guy Jr. In his leisure time, Richard was an avid mountaineer.

title: Native American groups sue US state of Montana over ballot law
content:
On Thursday, the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) of Montana filed a lawsuit against the state over its 2018 Ballot Interference Prevention Act (BIPA), arguing that the law would disenfranchise many Native American voters.

According to reports, the majority of Montanans cast their votes by mail, with 73% utilizing this method. Many residents of Montana's Native American reservations lack access to reliable transportation, making it difficult for them to reach voting sites. Consequently, these individuals often complete their ballots and rely on voting organizations to deliver them to election offices. However, BIPA restricts ballot collection by limiting each carrier to six ballots from others, down from the previous limit of 80, unless they are immediate family members. Violating this law could result in a $500 fine.

Jacqueline De León from the ACLU stated, "BIPA disregards the everyday challenges faced by Native American communities. Expecting voters to drive an hour just to drop off their ballots is unreasonable; it's logical to collect ballots within reservation communities. Criminalizing this process is unjust and does not address the underlying issue of mail delivery to Native homes."

Supporters of BIPA, including state legislators, argue that it is designed to combat voter fraud by preventing individuals from collecting and potentially discarding ballots based on the voters' preferences. Montana's Secretary of State defended the law, asserting that it has substantial support among Montanans, including those in Indian Country, and criticized attempts to overturn the will of the people.

As of 2020, approximately 70,000 people lived across seven Native American reservations in Montana, which has a total population of just over one million.

Included as plaintiffs in the suit are organizations such as Western Native Voice, Montana Native Vote, and the Assiniboine and Sioux Tribes of Fort Peck. The lawsuit was filed in [insert relevant court/jurisdiction].

A significant issue raised in the suit is BIPA's definition of "family." The complaint highlights that many Native American cultures in Montana have a broader understanding of family that diverges from the traditional Western concept.
question:
What is the maximum number of ballots that a non-family member was previously allowed to deliver under Montana's Ballot Interference Prevention Act (BIPA) before its restrictions were tightened?

title: Stores in Australia lower toilet paper limits per transaction
content:
On Saturday and Sunday evenings, major Australian supermarket chains Woolworths and Coles reduced their purchase limits on toilet paper to two and one pack per transaction nationwide, respectively. ALDI followed suit on Monday, implementing a one-pack limit as well. These restrictions were communicated through messages at checkouts and on the chains' Facebook pages, prompted by heightened consumer demand linked to concerns about COVID-19 and potential self-isolation. Additionally, Woolworths announced on Wednesday that customers could only purchase one pack of toilet paper for home delivery.

This change follows the earlier introduction of a four-pack purchase limit by Woolworths on March 4 and by Coles on March 5. In a March 8 media release, Coles noted that despite the restrictions, many stores were still selling out within an hour of their deliveries, calling the demand "unprecedented." ALDI described the situation as "unexpected" in a Tuesday Facebook post. A spokesperson from Woolworths confirmed a "sharp increase" in sales last week. A store in Canberra also imposed a two-pack limit last week.

To help alleviate the shortage, Coles has ordered larger packages from suppliers and increased delivery frequencies. Woolworths has also ordered extra stock, while ALDI made its planned special stock available early. Russell Zimmerman, the executive director of the Australian Retailers Association, highlighted that although retailers are trying to boost their inventory, local council restrictions on delivery timings complicate the process. He anticipates rising production costs as suppliers attempt to meet demand, along with fewer promotional specials. ALDI announced on Tuesday that due to the early release of stock, some stores would not be able to run their scheduled Wednesday specials.

In a report, Dr. Gary Mortimer, a retail expert from Queensland University of Technology, pointed out that stores restock every night. He noted that toilet paper is a bulky item, which leads to lower quantities on shelves. When sold out, the empty shelf space exacerbates the perception of a shortage. Zimmerman added that if products like toilet paper and hand sanitizers were available in ample quantities, it could help reduce consumer panic, as reported by ABC News.

Meanwhile, recycled toilet paper producer Who Gives a Crap announced on Wednesday that it had run out of stock. Both Kimberly-Clark, the manufacturer of Kleenex Toilet Tissue, and Solaris Paper, producer of Sorbent, have emphasized that they are working around the clock to maintain supply, according to a report from News.com.au.

In an unusual trend, domain.com reported that some property sellers in Melbourne began offering free toilet paper to the first bidder at auctions, coinciding with a decrease in auctions during the long weekend. Additionally, the Thursday edition of the Daily Telegraph included an eight-page insert designed for cutting and using as toilet paper.

Initially, stores had been hesitant to impose restrictions; an ABC Australia report from March 3 indicated that they had no immediate plans to introduce purchasing limits.

Zimmerman also noted that other products are experiencing high demand, including masks, sanitizers, dried goods, handwash, and flour. Outside of Australia, British supermarket Tesco was observed limiting purchases of toilet paper to two 12-roll packs on Sunday evening.

title: Sultan Qaboos of Oman dies
content:
On Friday, Oman’s long-serving Sultan, Qaboos bin Said al Said, passed away at the age of 79 after recently battling health issues, including colon cancer. Tributes were paid by world leaders, including Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif and UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

In response to his death, the Omani government declared three days of mourning. Prior to Qaboos's burial in a family cemetery, his successor, Haitham bin Tariq al Said, attended funeral prayers at the Grand Mosque in Muscat.

Qaboos ascended to the throne in 1970 after a bloodless coup that overthrew his father, Sultan Said. At the time of his death, he had the longest reign in the Arab world, known for his neutral foreign policy and his role as a mediator in several regional disputes, famously contributing to the negotiations that led to the 2015 Iran nuclear deal.

Concerns had been mounting regarding Qaboos's health in the months leading up to his death. He spent a week in a Belgian hospital before returning to Oman in mid-December, but details about his medical treatment remained undisclosed.

Born in 1940, Qaboos received his education in India and the United Kingdom, followed by a cultural tour of the globe. Upon returning to Oman in 1964, he focused on studying Islamic law and Omani history.

His 1970 coup, backed by the British, initiated a series of reforms that transformed Oman from a poorly developed nation into a relatively prosperous state.

As Qaboos had no children, Omani law stipulated that a royal council had three days to select a successor. If the council could not reach a decision, they would then open a sealed letter left by Qaboos naming his chosen heir.

When the council convened, they opted to open the letter, which revealed Qaboos’s cousin, Haitham, as the new Sultan. Following the funeral, Haitham affirmed his intention to uphold Qaboos's policies, including a commitment to maintaining a neutral stance in foreign affairs.

title: World Health Organization names new coronavirus COVID-19
content:
On Tuesday, the World Health Organization (WHO) officially named the coronavirus-related disease that was first identified approximately two months ago in China: "COVID-19," replacing its temporary designation "2019-nCoV."

It's important to note that "COVID-19" refers to the disease itself, while the virus responsible for it has been named "severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2" (SARS-CoV-2).

The name "COVID-19" reflects its components: "COVI" denotes the coronavirus, "D" stands for "disease," and "19" indicates the year it was first detected, which is 2019.

According to WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the name was chosen to be easy to pronounce and to avoid stigmatization, adhering to WHO guidelines established in 2015 that discourage using specific names related to individuals, animals, professions, or geographical locations.

These guidelines were influenced by past outbreaks, such as the 2009 H1N1 pandemic, which was commonly referred to as "swine flu." This labeling led the Egyptian government to cull over 300,000 pigs, a decision criticized as unnecessary by the chief veterinary officer of the United Nations' Food and Agriculture Organization. The guidelines also highlight that naming diseases after regions, like the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome from 2013, is discouraged.

Public health expert Wendy Parmet emphasized in an interview with Time magazine that naming the virus after Wuhan would lead to "tremendous stigmatization" of its residents. She warned that such associations can discourage communities from reporting health issues for fear of being labeled as disease-prone. Parmet reiterated the need for a name that is easy to remember and unlikely to become associated with negative connotations.

Medical anthropologist Monica Schoch-Spana further noted that individuals from diverse national, ethnic, or religious backgrounds have historically faced unfounded accusations of spreading disease, regardless of scientific evidence. Reports have already surfaced of people avoiding or harassing Chinese individuals, or those perceived as such, in several countries including Italy, the United States, Thailand, and Canada due to the current outbreak.

As of Tuesday, the SARS-CoV-2 virus has claimed over 1,000 lives and infected tens of thousands worldwide.

What is the official name of the disease caused by the coronavirus first recognized in China?

A) SARS-CoV-2

"We're used to it," one resident told Paul Rivera from the news outlet. In light of the unusual seismic activity over the past month, seismologists have deployed buried sensors to investigate its causes.

Repair efforts faced setbacks from continuing aftershocks, and approximately two-thirds of the island remained without power two days after the January 7 quake, which devastated around 300 homes, damaged roads, resulted in one fatality and eight injuries, and compromised Puerto Rico's largest power plant. The island's governor, Wanda Vázquez Garced, declared a state of emergency.

This earthquake followed a 5.8 magnitude quake the previous day that caused the collapse of a well-known rock formation.

According to José Ortiz from the island's power authority, repairs on the damaged Costa Sur power plant—located near the epicenter of the January 7 quake—could take up to a year. Costa Sur was responsible for supplying power to about a quarter of Puerto Rico's residential and commercial sectors. Without its operation, other power plants will have to run near full capacity to meet the needs of residents.

Puerto Rico is still struggling to recover from the devastation of Hurricane Maria in 2017, which caused approximately $90 billion in damages and claimed around 3,000 lives.

The USGS has indicated that aftershocks and seismic activity may persist into early February.
