title: GitHub blocks public access to youtube-dl after RIAA issues DMCA notice
content:
On Friday, GitHub, the popular code hosting and sharing platform, restricted public access to the repository of youtube-dl, a widely-used software that enables users to download videos from various websites, including YouTube. This action followed a takedown request issued under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA). After removing the personal information included in the notice, GitHub made the notice publicly accessible on its platform.

Originally created in July 2008 by Ricardo Garcia, youtube-dl is an open-source tool written in Python that allows users to download videos from multiple sources. It is free and open-source software (FLOSS), licensed under the MIT License. Currently, only the maintainers of the project can view the locked repository on GitHub.

The RIAA's DMCA notice claimed that the software's primary function was to "circumvent the technological protection measures" used by authorized streaming services like YouTube and to "reproduce and distribute music videos and sound recordings owned by our member companies without authorization." Furthermore, the notice highlighted certain tests in the youtube-dl source code designed to determine whether the software could download various types of content, including Creative Commons licensed videos and age-restricted content. The RIAA asserted that aspects of these tests indicated intentional design to bypass YouTube's protections.

The RIAA’s notice cited a violation of 17 U.S. Code § 1201, which prohibits circumvention of technological measures controlling access to copyrighted works. The notice called for the removal of several forks of youtube-dl from GitHub as well.

Significantly, the RIAA's notice did not provide evidence of any specific instance where youtube-dl had been used to download or share copyrighted material, nor did it address any resultant damages. Importantly, many videos on YouTube are available under Creative Commons licenses, allowing users to legally share and modify them with proper attribution. Additionally, a range of content, including videos in the public domain, can be accessed on YouTube without restrictions.

Thousands of users around the world rely on youtube-dl, which also facilitates the download of Creative Commons-licensed and public domain videos for archival projects. The software is also employed to capture multimedia content from platforms like LiveLeak, and users sometimes utilize it for creating backups or collecting evidence.

youtube-dl operates via a lightweight command-line interface that mimics browser behavior when retrieving video data from servers. It includes various "extractors" to handle content from diverse sources, demonstrating that it essentially downloads media in a way similar to standard web browsing. However, unlike traditional browsing, which may have ephemeral access limitations, downloading via tools like youtube-dl can yield persistent copies of content.

The decision to restrict access led to considerable backlash on social media, with users expressing their frustration on platforms like Twitter. Some criticized reliance on centralized services like GitHub, arguing for a return to decentralized software development practices enabled by systems like Git.

In the wake of the GitHub actions, users began sharing the source code through self-hosted Git servers, leading to what is known as the Streisand Effect — the phenomenon where attempts to suppress information only lead to its increased spread. While public access to the repository is restricted, binaries of the software remain available on its official site, with some users employing innovative methods to propagate the source code, such as encoding it into images.

The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) commented on the incident, stating, "Youtube-dl is a legitimate tool with a world of lawful uses. Demanding its removal from GitHub is a disappointing and counterproductive move by the RIAA." Richard Stallman, founder of the Free Software Foundation, has likewise expressed strong criticism of Digital Rights Management (DRM) practices associated with the DMCA for years.

Wikinews reached out to Sergey M., one of the maintainers of youtube-dl, for comment. Sergey indicated he was unable to provide detailed responses at that moment but later shared an update in an IRC channel. He noted that GitHub's reinstatement conditions involved a complete removal of certain code related to YouTube’s security measures, which he found unsatisfactory but could potentially comply with to restore access.

The EFF has not yet responded to questions from Wikinews. Additionally, former youtube-dl maintainer Philipp Hagemeister was contacted for insights on the takedown. He revealed that he first learned about the DMCA notice from Reddit and expressed his thoughts on youtube-dl’s legal standing, the nature of its DRM circumvention, and potential next steps for the project.

As users continue to navigate these challenges, the wider implications of this takedown on open-source software and digital rights remain a topic of significant discussion in technology and legal circles.

A) It was due to a violation of privacy policies.  
B) GitHub received a Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) take-down notice from the RIAA.  
C) The maintainers decided to discontinue the software.  
D) Users reported malicious activity related to the software.

title: Open source game developer Perttu Ahola talks about Minetest with Wikinews
content:
**Open Source Game Developer Perttu Ahola Discusses Minetest with Wikinews**

Finnish open-source game developer Perttu Ahola recently spoke with Wikinews about Minetest, which he describes as his "longest ever project." 

Minetest was initiated in October 2010 as Ahola's endeavor to create an alternative to the popular commercial game, Minecraft. At the time, Minecraft was a multi-platform title still in its developmental stages, and Ahola sought to build a similar experience from the ground up.

Unlike Minecraft, which costs $26.95 for its computer version and is owned by Microsoft, Minetest is open-source and free for anyone to download and play. According to Ahola, Minetest is designed to run efficiently on older hardware with limited graphics capabilities, allowing more individuals to access the game without any cost.

A correspondent from French Wikinews first contacted Ahola several weeks ago, leading to this in-depth interview to explore more about this nearly decade-long project.

**Introduction to Perttu Ahola**

"Hi, I’m Perttu Ahola, known as 'celeron55' online. I'm a programming enthusiast and geek from Finland," he introduced himself.

**Early Beginnings and Motivation**

Ahola shared that programming has been a lifelong hobby. "As a child, I programmed on my dad's computers and later took formal programming courses in school and university."

His motivation for creating Minetest stemmed from an initial challenge, which evolved into an exploration of what could be achieved in gaming that a corporate entity like Microsoft might overlook. "I was curious about how a game world works under the hood," he explained.

**Development Journey**

Ahola began working on Minetest in October 2010, starting solo until the first contributor joined six months later. The initial public release was shared within a private IRC channel for testing, followed by a public debut on a programming channel soon after.

"The first users were hobbyist programmers who enjoyed the quirky multiplayer experience," he recalled.

**Current Development Team**

Today, the Minetest development team comprises 13 core developers, though the number of active contributors fluctuates. "Core development is about trust and deciding what gets merged, so not all contributors hold that title," he noted.

**Workflow and Changes**

Describing his workflow, Ahola said, "I allocate as much continuous time as possible for tasks, starting with writing prototypes that evolve into final implementations." This approach contrasts sharply with more structured development models, focusing instead on iterative progress.

Significant evolutionary changes to Minetest have come from building on prior iterations, with one major upgrade shifting from version 0.3 to 0.4, which introduced a content-based engine that fundamentally altered user perceptions.

**Community Engagement and Contributions**

Ahola emphasized the importance of community in Minetest, stating that users are encouraged to create and share mods, set up servers, or document experiences through screenshots on forums. "The beauty of Minetest is that it empowers people to use it for various purposes, whether for education or prototyping games," he said.

However, Ahola highlighted the decentralized nature of contributions, noting that there is no single figure managing patches or improvements. Instead, the project thrives on voluntary collaboration, with users taking initiative based on their interests.

**Future Plans and Challenges**

Looking ahead, Ahola referenced ongoing discussions among developers regarding future updates, which include planned releases with new gameplay features. Yet, he cautioned against setting unrealistic milestones in a hobbyist project. "Great ideas often come but don’t always materialize due to varying contributor engagement," he admitted.

**Concluding Thoughts**

Reflecting on the significance of Minetest and its journey, he remarked on how the community's involvement shapes its direction. "The project depends on users enjoying it. If it resonates with people, that's what matters."

In a world dominated by commercial entities, Ahola's passion for open-source gaming continues to inspire many, offering a platform for creativity, learning, and collaboration without monetary barriers.

**Monthly Update: 2020 U.S. Presidential Election Highlights - August Edition**

This is the fourth installment of our monthly series tracking the 2020 United States presidential election, featuring highlights and analysis of significant events from the past month.

This month’s campaign trail includes a bizarre incident where a bat attacks Libertarian Party candidate Jo Jorgensen, the American Independent Party (AIP) gets embroiled in controversy with its presidential ticket selection, and renewed questions about the eligibility of Democratic vice presidential nominee Kamala Harris.

In head-to-head polling as August began, presumptive Democratic nominee Joe Biden led incumbent President Donald Trump, the GOP nominee, with 49.4% to 42.0%. Amidst the campaign, early August saw heated discussions following Trump's late July tweet alleging that voting by mail could lead to fraud. Changes made by Louis DeJoy, the new Postmaster General appointed by Trump, resulted in delays in mail service, raising accusations that Trump was intentionally creating obstacles to mail-in voting. While DeJoy insisted that the U.S. Postal Service could manage the influx of mail-in ballots due to the pandemic, Democrats in Congress called for additional funding to mitigate any potential voter disenfranchisement. Trump expressed support for blocking emergency relief measures as a strategy against an increase in mail-in voting, and Biden condemned this approach, suggesting it indicated Trump's reluctance for the election to occur. Trump also continued to voice concerns about fraud in mail-in voting, filing lawsuits against certain states' procedures, particularly a Nevada law that mandated ballots be sent to all registered voters.

Biden made history by selecting Senator Kamala Harris of California as his running mate, fulfilling his promise to choose a woman for the position. This choice drew criticism from Trump, who referred to Harris as "phony" and alleged that her previous attacks on Biden during debates were disingenuous. The selection sparked renewed questions from some, mainly within the AIP, regarding Harris's eligibility, echoing similar unfounded claims made about former President Barack Obama. The AIP subsequently nominated a ticket featuring Rocky De La Fuente and rapper Kanye West, without previously consulting West, who is also pursuing his own presidential campaign primarily through the Birthday Party.

In the wake of these developments, Donald Trump’s younger brother passed away from an undisclosed illness, with Biden and Harris expressing their condolences. Observers speculated whether the death was tied to COVID-19, leading to the viral spread of the hashtag #WrongTrump on Twitter, suggesting a morbid wish for the President's demise. 

The Democratic National Convention took place in a predominantly virtual format due to the pandemic, featuring pre-recorded speeches and live business sessions held in Wisconsin. Numerous speakers criticized Trump's handling of COVID-19. Biden was officially nominated, becoming the oldest major party nominee for president at age 77. The convention included messages from three former presidents—Jimmy Carter, Bill Clinton, and Barack Obama—as well as comments from Republicans like former Ohio Governor John Kasich and family members of George Floyd, who died in police custody, sparking widespread protests this summer. Michelle Obama delivered the keynote address, urging voters to support Biden, and Harris formally accepted the vice presidential nomination, marking her as the first Black woman nominated for the role.

Conversely, Trump criticized the convention as "dark" and "gloomy" and cast doubt on Biden’s commitment to combating the pandemic. Opinion polls indicated no significant convention bounce for Biden, whereas Trump appeared to gain ground in the nationwide polls, trimming Biden's lead by the end of August.

On the campaign front, Jo Jorgensen's August kicked off dramatically with a bat attack at her South Carolina home that resulted in her needing precautionary rabies shots. After sharing her experience on Twitter, the story gained traction across various media outlets. Meanwhile, the AIP nominated De La Fuente and West, igniting controversy over De La Fuente’s previous financial interactions with the party’s vice chairman and concerns regarding the AIP's motive in possibly aiding Trump’s campaign.

Lastly, significant discourse surrounded Harris's natural-born citizenship status. Critics have drawn parallels between this scrutiny and the "birther" controversies faced by Obama. Legal experts overwhelmingly dismiss these claims, affirming that Harris meets the requirements for eligibility. Nonetheless, vocal dissenters continue to express doubts, with some framing the debate as an extension of past challenges against Obama’s qualifications. 

With the election approaching, the dynamics continue to shift amid controversies, campaigning, and public discourse.

content:
**Monthly Series: Update on the 2020 U.S. Presidential Election - September Edition**

This is the fifth installment of our monthly series covering the developments of the 2020 United States presidential election. This edition includes original reports compiled over the past month, highlighting significant stories.

**Key Developments on the Campaign Trail:** 
- Libertarian Party presidential nominee Jo Jorgensen has achieved ballot access across all 50 states, marking a significant milestone for third-party candidates.
- Bill Hammons, the Unity Party of America presidential nominee, proposed an innovative approach to address concerns over "packing" the U.S. Supreme Court.
- Candidates shared their perspectives on the escalating military conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan.

As September commenced, Democratic nominee Joe Biden held a lead over President Donald Trump in the average head-to-head polling, 49.0% to 43.0%.

Trump began the month in Wisconsin, a state grappling with unrest following police incidents in August. He characterized the situation as "domestic terror" and emphasized the need for law and order. Biden responded in a fundraising message, accusing Trump of "trying to scare the hell out of America." Two days later, Biden visited Kenosha, where he spoke on racial inequality and met with the family of Jacob Blake. The Trump campaign criticized Biden for not denouncing violence and for visiting despite health concerns related to COVID-19. Wisconsin’s Democrat governor, Tony Evers, expressed a preference for neither candidate to visit.

Three controversies arose around Trump early in September. First, following speculation from CNN about his health during a visit to Walter Reed last November, Trump asserted that media claims of "mini-strokes" were false. He criticized CNN's reporting while demanding the network fire a specific journalist. Next, Trump faced allegations he insulted U.S. soldiers during a trip to France in 2018, with confirmations of parts of the story from sources like Fox News. Finally, excerpts from journalist Bob Woodward's book indicated Trump downplayed the coronavirus threat in February to prevent public panic, a claim Biden labeled as "almost criminal."

At a North Carolina interview and a rally in Pennsylvania, Trump stirred further controversy by suggesting supporters fill out absentee ballots and then vote in person if their ballots were not counted—an act classified as voting twice, which is illegal. After his tweet prompted a warning from Twitter, Trump’s team stated his comments were misinterpreted.

In mid-September, Trump hosted his first indoor rally in three months in Nevada, ignoring state COVID-19 guidelines. He later visited California to discuss the devastating wildfires, denying that climate change was a significant factor and attributing the fires to forest management issues. Biden labeled Trump a "climate arsonist" during a speech in Delaware, warning that environmental disasters would escalate if Trump were re-elected. 

Meanwhile, in Florida, recent polls indicated a growing support for Trump, possibly linked to his social conservative stances and opposition to socialism. Biden's team expressed concerns about acquiring Latino votes as his running mate Kamala Harris campaigned in the state. In a significant boost for Biden, former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg pledged to invest $100 million in Florida and assist former inmates in regaining voting rights—an initiative Trump declared as illegal.

Following a peace deal brokered between Israel and the United Arab Emirates, the Trump administration announced new agreements recognizing Israel’s diplomatic relations with both Bahrain and Serbia, in a move Trump called a "new Middle East." Concurrently, the conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan escalated, prompting discussions among presidential candidates regarding U.S. involvement.

The month also witnessed the passing of Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, prompting debates over her replacement. Trump nominated Amy Coney Barrett, leading to calls from some Democrats for court expansion to ensure ideological balance. Amid these developments, Trump refused to guarantee a peaceful transfer of power, claiming potential fraud due to increased mail-in voting—a statement criticized by both parties.

As September concluded, Biden maintained his lead in the RealClearPolitics polling average at 49.7% to Trump's 43.1%.

The Libertarian candidate Jo Jorgensen celebrated her campaign's full ballot access in all states. In her message to supporters, she expressed gratitude for the efforts of volunteers and staff. Jorgensen is campaigning for inclusion in presidential debates, arguing that her campaign is a viable alternative to both major parties.

The September edition also touched on the consequences of Ginsburg's death and the subsequent Supreme Court vacancy. While discussions about court packing have resurfaced, candidate Bill Hammons proposed a balanced approach to prevent further partisan shifts in judicial appointments.

The conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan, centered on the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region, saw renewed violence, with both sides claiming aggression and casualties. Candidates Jorgensen and Blankenship emphasized a non-interventionist U.S. foreign policy.

In closing, September proved to be a defining month in the lead-up to the election, with candidates navigating controversies, electoral strategies, and positioning on critical national and international issues.

**South Carolina Professor and Libertarian Presidential Nominee Jo Jorgensen Shares Insights on Her Campaign**

Jo Jorgensen, a psychology professor from South Carolina and the Libertarian Party's nominee for the 2020 presidential election, recently engaged in an interview with accredited Wikinews reporter William S. Saturn.

Jorgensen first entered the political arena in 1992, running for a seat in the U.S. House of Representatives with the support of the Libertarian Party. Although she finished third, garnering just over 2.16% of the vote, she later became the party's vice presidential nominee in 1996 alongside the late Harry Browne. Together, they appeared on ballots across the nation and secured approximately 485,798 votes, equating to about 0.5% of the total—a record performance for the party at the time, which held until it was surpassed in 2012 by Gary Johnson, who received 0.99% in his campaign.

During her quest for the 2020 nomination, Jorgensen faced tough competition in a primary campaign that included former Rhode Island Governor Lincoln Chafee and Congressman Justin Amash of Michigan, the first sitting congressman to join the Libertarian Party. Ultimately, she clinched the nomination on the fourth ballot after overcoming challenges from notable figures like Vermin Supreme and Jacob Hornberger, with Mike ter Maat joining her as vice presidential nominee. The Jorgensen-Cohen ticket secured ballot access in all 50 states and the District of Columbia.

As a staunch libertarian advocating for limited government intervention, Jorgensen's platform blends liberal and conservative views. She is a proponent of both LGBT rights and gun rights, and she stands against the expansion of police powers and broad taxation. Additionally, she endorses an open immigration policy while voicing opposition to the welfare state.

In her conversation with Wikinews, Jorgensen addressed a variety of topics ranging from her personal background and the COVID-19 pandemic to climate change and race relations.

**Question: Which past leader do you admire most and why?**

**Jo Jorgensen:** "I admire Thomas Jefferson, who wrote the Declaration of Independence. I'd amend the phrase 'all men are created equal' to 'all people are created equal!'"

**Question: How have your experiences prepared you for the presidency?**

**Jorgensen:** "The most critical preparation is understanding that people thrive when free to manage their own lives without governmental interference. My grandmother, an immigrant from Denmark, instilled in me a passion for freedom, and my life experiences have reinforced that government should primarily protect life, liberty, and property."

**Question: How would you characterize your leadership style in comparison to Presidents Trump and Obama?**

**Jorgensen:** "My style emphasizes individual liberty and scrutinizing any proposal for government force. This stands in stark contrast to both Trump and Obama, who have embraced broader government powers."

**Question: How would your response to the COVID-19 pandemic differ from President Trump's?**

**Jorgensen:** "I would have ensured that the CDC and FDA did not hinder access to tests and treatments from the free market. Recognizing the virus's primary threat to vulnerable populations, I would have advocated for personal responsibility over lockdowns."

**Question: How has the pandemic impacted your campaign strategy?**

title: Wikinews interviews Brian Carroll, American Solidarity Party presidential nominee
content:
**Retired Teacher Brian Carroll Discusses Presidential Campaign with Wikinews**

Brian Carroll, the presidential nominee of the American Solidarity Party, recently outlined his campaign in an interview with Wikinews reporter William S. Saturn.

Carroll, a retired educator with 44 years of experience, primarily taught history to elementary students in California. He also spent nine years teaching in Colombia for children of U.S. military personnel. Carroll entered politics by joining the Solidarity Party and ran for Congress in 2018, finishing fifth with 1.3% of the vote. He secured the Solidarity Party's presidential nomination in September 2019, defeating fellow candidates Joshua Perkins and a previous Wikinews interviewee. Carroll selected fellow educator Amar Patel as his running mate, who spoke to Wikinews in August.

The Solidarity Party, established in 2011 as the Christian Democratic Party, emphasizes Roman Catholic social teaching, advocating for social justice, environmentalism, and a multicultural society, including opposition to violence, racism, and sectarianism. The party rebranded ahead of the 2016 election, where its first ticket received a total of 6,777 votes, primarily through write-ins in Colorado. The party has expanded its ballot access in preparation for the 2020 election, securing positions in eight states and write-in access in an additional 23.

In his conversation with Wikinews, Carroll shared insights about his background, COVID-19's impact on campaigning, presidential nominations, and his views on pressing issues such as climate change, foreign policy, and internet speech.

**Q: Which past president do you most admire and why?**  
**Brian Carroll:** My two childhood heroes were Thomas Jefferson and Benjamin Franklin, who had a profound curiosity and pursued their interests relentlessly. I shaped my own educational goals accordingly. Over time, I recognized the more complex sides of historical figures, including Jefferson. I focused on teaching history for 40 years, highlighting both the positive and negative impacts of various presidents, including both Abraham Lincoln and Woodrow Wilson. Recently, I've gained an appreciation for Ulysses S. Grant, especially his decisive actions against the Ku Klux Klan during his presidency.

**Q: How have your past experiences prepared you for the job of President?**  
**Brian Carroll:** As a teacher, I constantly explain complex concepts, much like a politician does. Additionally, my efforts have often centered on raising community awareness on critical issues, a fundamental aspect of political engagement.

**Q: How would you describe your style of leadership? How does it compare to Donald Trump's and Barack Obama's?**  
**Brian Carroll:** I consider myself the "unTrump." I am confident and secure enough to embrace expert opinions. Like Jefferson, I have diverse interests and a collaborative approach, though I feel more comfortable in public speaking than he did. I intend to hire an organized staff to help keep my administration focused.

**Q: If you were president, how would you have handled the COVID-19 pandemic differently than President Trump?**  
**Brian Carroll:** I would not have dismissed the pandemic preparedness plan left by Obama. I would have acted proactively to mobilize American industries to produce necessary equipment.

**Q: How has the pandemic affected your campaign?**  
**Brian Carroll:** The pandemic has limited my travel and made it more challenging to gather signatures for ballots. However, it has also allowed me valuable time at home with my wife, which has been a positive aspect amidst the challenges many face.

**Q: In the 2016 election, your party's nominee garnered 6,777 votes. What are your expectations for the upcoming election?**  
**Brian Carroll:** I believe we will exceed that number significantly, possibly by a factor of ten or twenty.

**Q: What would a Carroll administration look like?**  
**Brian Carroll:** I won't name specific individuals before reaching out, but I would invite key advisors to suggest candidates and consult with congressional caucuses known for bipartisan cooperation to form my Cabinet.

**Q: Who would you nominate to the Supreme Court?**  
**Brian Carroll:** I believe many of us have been misled by judges who favor business interests over those of workers and consumers. My focus would shift that priority.

**Q: How will you work with Congress to enhance bipartisanship?**  
**Brian Carroll:** I will emphasize a Cabinet that fosters collaboration and signal that bipartisan cooperation is essential for success. 

**Q: What measures should the government take to address global climate change?**  
**Brian Carroll:** We are at a critical juncture and must reduce our carbon footprint by embracing renewable energy sources, assessing practical applications of wind, solar, and other technologies, and exploring innovative solutions.

**Q: What is your stance on the conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan?**  
**Brian Carroll:** I advocate for a diplomatic resolution without military intervention.

**Q: What are your views on censorship of certain opinions on social media?**  
**Brian Carroll:** Social media is still maturing, and while it struggles with the complexities of free speech, I believe patience and persistence will help us reach a more equitable situation.

**Q: How would you improve racial equity and justice?**  
**Brian Carroll:** A key starting point would be to publicly commit to prioritizing these issues. Initiatives like the recent "Contract with Black America" feature numerous constructive ideas, though realizing them all in the first 100 days may be unrealistic. A visible commitment will be crucial from day one.

**Q: As Election Day approaches, what final message do you have for voters?**  
**Brian Carroll:** Many citizens feel disenfranchised, but this is their opportunity to support a party that aligns with their values. The major parties often focus on fear, but the American Solidarity Party represents hope for a better future.

This is the sixth and final installment in our monthly series detailing the 2020 United States presidential election. It features key updates from the campaign trail over the past month, alongside a recap of significant events.

In October, the political landscape was defined by two presidential debates and the final appeals of three candidates who opted out of the debates. Three political analysts also weighed in with their predictions for the election outcome.

As the campaign entered its final month, polling averages indicated that Democratic nominee Joe Biden was ahead of Republican incumbent Donald Trump, with support at 50.1% to 42.9%.

**The Month in Review:**

October began dramatically when President Trump, his wife Melania, and their son Barron tested positive for COVID-19 after a staff aide contracted the virus. Trump experienced minor symptoms and was hospitalized as a precaution. Footage showed him wearing a mask while being transported to Walter Reed Medical Center. He was treated with a combination of medications, including an experimental drug and the steroid dexamethasone. After a three-day hospital stay, he returned to the White House, assuring the public not to fear COVID-19.

Shortly after Trump's release, the only vice presidential debate took place, featuring Vice President Mike Pence and Democratic nominee Kamala Harris in Utah. The debate was noted for its civility compared to the earlier Trump-Biden clash. A notable moment occurred when a fly landed in Pence's hair, drawing immediate media attention. 

Amid discussions of the Supreme Court confirmation hearings for Amy Coney Barrett, Biden and Harris dodged questions about "court-packing." Biden later stated that 56% of respondents who believe their situation has improved in the past four years were mistaken.

Trump returned to the campaign trail shortly after his recovery, hosting rallies in Florida, where he claimed to be "immune" and even joked about kissing supporters. Meanwhile, Biden held a town hall that drew more viewers than a competing one held by Trump the same night.

In an "October surprise," the New York Post reported on emails from a laptop allegedly owned by Hunter Biden, suggesting potential ethical violations involving international business dealings. This accusation was met with controversy, as intelligence officials warned of potential misinformation linked to the allegations. Social media platforms responded to the story with varying degrees of censorship, prompting backlash from critics of their policies.

Just before the final debate, Hunter Biden's former business partner claimed that Joe Biden was involved in his son's dealings, which Biden fiercely denied during the second presidential debate. The debate showcased sharp exchanges on issues like healthcare, climate change, and the economy. 

As Halloween approached, Trump intensified his campaign efforts, holding multiple rallies daily across key battleground states. In contrast, Biden's campaign focused on smaller, socially distanced events.

Significant developments included the Senate confirmation of Judge Barrett and the announcement of a deal to normalize relations between Sudan and Israel. Additionally, widespread protests erupted in Philadelphia following the police killing of a mentally ill Black man.

By the end of October, polling data indicated Trump trailing Biden in national averages, while some independent candidates were also making final appeals to voters ahead of Election Day. 

**Predictions from Political Analysts:**

Former U.S. Congressman Tom Tancredo projected a Trump victory with an electoral count of 362 to 176. Political blogger Thomas Knapp, however, foresees a Biden win at 319 to 219. Attorney Ron Gunzburger also predicted a Biden victory, estimating the electoral count at 359 to 179.

As we head towards the election, the outcome remains uncertain, emphasizing the importance of voter engagement in this pivotal moment in U.S. history.

He emphasized the importance of engaging the electorate to foster discussions on social justice and environmental sustainability.

Bodenstab praised his partnership with Bill Hammons, explaining their vision for expanding the Unity Party's reach. "We aim to foster grassroots connections while emphasizing that ordinary citizens can initiate change through collective action," he noted, sharing insights into their campaign efforts in states like Colorado, Louisiana, and New Jersey.

title: Red Hat to move focus away from CentOS in favour of Stream; CentOS team discuss implications with Wikinews
content:
**Red Hat Shifts Focus from CentOS to CentOS Stream, Community Voices Concerns**

On Tuesday, the U.S.-based software company Red Hat announced a significant shift in its focus from CentOS to CentOS Stream, sparking discussions within the community and among CentOS project members.

In a blog post, Red Hat’s Chief Technology Officer stated that the company has officially informed the CentOS governing board of the decision to "shift our investment fully from CentOS Linux to CentOS Stream." Notably, at least five of the nine board members are employees of Red Hat.

Founded in 2004, CentOS provided a free and open-source alternative to Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL), Red Hat’s commercial OS. The CentOS project was absorbed by Red Hat in 2014, giving the company control over the CentOS trademark.

It's worth noting that Red Hat also sponsors the Fedora operating system, which has traditionally served as the upstream source for RHEL. Previously, software development occurred in Fedora before being incorporated into RHEL, followed by the release of CentOS, which mirrored RHEL without the associated support.

Introduced in September 2019—just months after Red Hat was acquired by IBM—CentOS Stream was designed to function as an upstream distribution, allowing community members and Red Hat to collaborate on new features before they are incorporated into RHEL. Unlike CentOS, which adhered to a traditional release cycle, CentOS Stream is updated more frequently and is ahead of RHEL in terms of new developments.

Wright emphasized that while CentOS Stream is not intended to replace CentOS Linux, it provides "a platform for rapid innovation at the community level, with a stable enough base to understand production dynamics." He views this transition as a step toward advancing enterprise Linux innovation.

The announcement has led to backlash from CentOS users across platforms including IRC, Reddit, and mailing lists. A significant change is the accelerated End of Life (EOL) for CentOS 8, now set for December 31, 2021, rather than May 2029, while CentOS 7 is expected to receive updates until June 2024.

In response to the announcement, Gregory Kurtzer, the founder of CentOS, announced the launch of a new community-driven operating system called Rocky Linux. This distribution aims to be "100% bug-for-bug compatible with Enterprise Linux," replicating the previous downstream approach of CentOS by building releases after they have been integrated with upstream vendors.

Wikinews spoke to CentOS project members Pablo Greco and Rich Bowen about the implications of this shift. Greco is a maintainer focused on 32-bit processors, whereas Bowen serves as the community manager of the CentOS project.

**Concerns and Future Directions**

The reaction from the community indicates strong feelings of betrayal, as many users feel the decision was made without adequate notice or input. "The future of CentOS Linux is now uncertain," said an anonymous community member. "With the shift to CentOS Stream, many users are left without a suitable alternative that offers the stability and support they relied on."

Bowen explained that while the restructuring aims to provide greater community involvement in the development process, many existing users may find CentOS Stream does not meet their needs. “We want to ensure that those who are impacted articulate their needs as the community adjusts to this change.”

Kurtzer believes that for those dissatisfied with CentOS Stream, alternatives include transitioning to RHEL or exploring other distributions.

Despite the upheaval, Red Hat insists that they are committed to maintaining an open development process and encouraging participation in CentOS Stream. They are also developing low- or no-cost programs for those unable to transition smoothly.

As CentOS pivots towards a new model, the challenge will be to meet user expectations while fostering an inclusive environment for community contributions. Whether CentOS Stream can fulfill the legacy of CentOS Linux remains to be seen, but the community’s response will undoubtedly shape its evolution moving forward.

title: Gregory Kurtzer discusses plans for Rocky Linux with Wikinews as Red Hat announces moving focus away from CentOS
content:
**Gregory Kurtzer Discusses the Future of Rocky Linux with Wikinews Following Red Hat's Shift Away from CentOS**

On December 8, Red Hat, a US-based software company, announced a strategic shift away from CentOS, previously a popular free alternative to its Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL).

Launched in 2004, CentOS was created as a free and open-source platform, providing a community-based environment with RHEL’s source code. Gregory Kurtzer, who founded CAOS Linux, explained to Wikinews that he initiated CAOS around the time Red Hat transitioned from community-supported Red Hat Linux (RHL) to a subscription-only model with RHEL. Kurtzer's initiative led to the development of CentOS when developer Rocky McGaugh rebuilt RHEL's source code to offer a free alternative. CentOS was integrated into Red Hat in 2014, granting Red Hat trademark rights to the name.

Red Hat also backs the development of Fedora, the upstream project that contributes to RHEL. Traditionally, CentOS mirrored RHEL’s release cycle, providing a stable and cost-free option for users without support. In September 2019, however, CentOS Stream was introduced, coinciding with Red Hat's acquisition by IBM. Unlike previous iterations, Stream adopts a rolling release model, integrating community and Red Hat developments before they enter RHEL, resulting in more frequent but less stable updates.

In the wake of Red Hat's announcement, which many users expressed dissatisfaction with on platforms such as IRC, Reddit, and the CentOS mailing list, the End of Life (EOL) for CentOS 8 was moved up from May 2029 to December 31, 2021. In contrast, CentOS 7 will continue to receive maintenance updates through June 2024.

In response to the changes, Kurtzer revealed plans for Rocky Linux—a new distribution aimed at fulfilling the role CentOS played. Named in honor of McGaugh, Kurtzer emphasized that Rocky Linux is designed to be “for the community.” He reassured users that decisions regarding the project would prioritize community interests, free from corporate influence, including that of his own company.

While a specific release date for Rocky Linux has not been set, Kurtzer anticipates its launch will occur before CentOS 8’s EOL. Rocky Linux will be compatible with both x86-64 and ARM architectures, allowing current CentOS users to transition seamlessly via a simple command.

Kurtzer highlighted the importance of maintaining a stable, community-driven distribution, stressing that Rocky Linux will ensure a “freely available version” of enterprise-grade software—respecting contributions from developers worldwide. “We are committed to providing a bug-for-bug compatible operating system that can be used freely by anyone,” he declared.

As for hardware support, Rocky Linux aims to cover the same range as CentOS, with preliminary interest in ARM architectures. The project has already garnered significant community interest, with around 65 active contributors and hundreds more volunteering to help.

Looking ahead, Kurtzer acknowledged growth as a primary challenge but expressed confidence in the support Rocky Linux has begun to receive. The end goal is to create a transparent, community-driven structure that prioritizes the interests of its users and fosters collaboration.

In summary, as Rocky Linux develops with community backing, it seeks to address the void left by Red Hat's changes and provide a trustworthy, accessible platform for users and developers alike.

title: 'Earth-based life can survive in hydrogen-rich atmospheres': MIT professor Dr Seager tells Wikinews about her research on organisms thriving in oxygen-less environment
content:
**Study Reveals Life Can Thrive in Hydrogen-Rich Environments, Says MIT Professor**

In May, a study published in a journal by Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) Professor Dr. [Name] and other researchers found that organisms like *Escherichia coli* (E. coli) and yeast can survive in both 100% hydrogen (H2) and helium (He) atmospheres. To delve deeper into these groundbreaking findings, Wikinews interviewed Dr. Seager about her research.

So far, life has only been observed in Earth's nitrogen-oxygen-rich atmosphere. While Earth's environment is primarily composed of nitrogen gas, oxygen plays a crucial role for complex organisms. Some microorganisms, known as anaerobes, do not rely on oxygen for metabolism. For instance, certain strains can utilize carbon dioxide while releasing methane.

In their experiment, researchers utilized the *E. coli* strain K-12 and the yeast strain *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* S288C. They subjected these microorganisms to four distinct environments: one with 100% air and three anaerobic settings, consisting of 100% H2, 100% He, and an 80%-20% N2-CO2 mix, all maintained at 28°C. To ensure the anaerobic conditions remained stable, the researchers installed oxygen sensors and monitored fluctuations in oxygen levels. They measured the growth rate of E. coli using optical density while employing a different method for the yeast.

The study revealed that both E. coli and yeast were able to reproduce normally in 100% hydrogen and helium environments. However, their growth rates were not as robust as those observed in a 100% air environment. The researchers noted that under these conditions, E. coli and yeast switched from aerobic respiration, which requires oxygen, to anaerobic respiration and fermentation. These processes are less efficient, resulting in reduced energy production compared to aerobic respiration.

In an 80%-20% N2-CO2 atmosphere, E. coli showed a slower growth rate due to the dissolving CO2, which made the liquid medium acidic. Conversely, yeast cultures flourished in acidic environments, but their growth rates in 100% air significantly surpassed those in hydrogen or helium environments. The research indicated that the growth impairment was likely due to the lack of oxygen for non-respiratory functions, which is essential for synthesizing important biochemicals like heme and sterols.

Dr. Seager emphasized that this discovery could lead astronomers to expand their search for habitable life on other planets. "There's a diversity of habitable worlds out there, and we've demonstrated that Earth-based life can survive in hydrogen-rich atmospheres. We should consider these planets as potential candidates for life," she stated.

She mentioned that detecting a planet with an extensive hydrogen-rich atmosphere could be feasible with advancing technologies. Hydrogen and helium have low densities, making them more expansive and easier to detect through telescopes. "The larger the atmosphere compared to the backdrop of a planet's star, the easier it is to observe," she explained.

The research paper noted that rocky planets with a radius less than 1.7 times that of Earth could maintain a hydrogen-rich atmosphere if water were to react with other elements.

Furthermore, the findings indicated that E. coli releases various gases in a hydrogen-based atmosphere, including hydrogen sulfide, methane, and ammonia. These gases can serve as biosignature markers, aiding astronomers in the search for potential life on exoplanets.

Highlighting the implications of this research, Dr. Seager stated, "Astronomers should maintain an open-minded approach when seeking life on distant planets." With NASA's upcoming initiatives set to launch next year, the study suggests that researchers could observe smaller exoplanets orbiting small red-dwarf stars.

Reflecting on her motivation for the study, Dr. Seager remarked, "We aimed to demonstrate that life could exist in hydrogen-rich environments, as these atmospheres are easier to analyze with current technologies compared to nitrogen or carbon dioxide-dominated atmospheres."

As the research continues, Dr. Seager and her team are excited about the possibilities it presents for astrobiology and the potential to identify signs of life beyond our solar system.

title: US federal agency announces plans to begin presidential transition process following Trump election loss
content:
On Monday, the United States General Services Administration (GSA) Administrator Emily Murphy sent a letter to President-elect Joe Biden and his team, granting them access to critical resources for the presidential transition process. This decision comes in the wake of the 2020 U.S. Presidential Election held on November 3, in which major national news outlets have projected that Biden defeated incumbent President Donald Trump.

Murphy emphasized that her decision was made independently, asserting that she was "never directly or indirectly pressured by any official." However, she revealed that she and her family had received threats of violence related to her role in facilitating access to federal documents for the incoming administration.

In response, President Trump, who appointed Murphy in 2017, took to Twitter to endorse the initiation of the presidential transition process, stating that it was "in the best interests of the country." This marked a significant shift in tone from his previous assertions that he had won the election, despite multiple states certifying results in favor of Biden.

While the president did not concede or acknowledge his defeat in his statement, he pledged to continue the fight through ongoing legal challenges to the election results in several swing states. As of now, his claims of widespread fraud have gained little traction in the courts. Just two days prior to Michigan's final certification of election results, a court dismissed a Trump lawsuit aimed at preventing Pennsylvania from certifying its results.

Trump and his legal team have faced criticism from both political parties for their fraud allegations. Biden and other members of the Democratic Party have expressed concern that the delayed transition could pose risks, as it withholds essential resources from Biden's team. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer noted that Trump's recent tweets may be as close as the public will get to an official concession from the president.

Some Republicans have distanced themselves from Trump, urging him to facilitate the transition. Former New Jersey Governor Chris Christie called the claims made by Trump’s legal team a "national embarrassment." Additionally, Trump ally and businessman David Bossie suggested that the president should accept the election results and "move on." Over 100 Republican national security experts signed an open letter encouraging party officials to prompt the president to concede.

Traditionally, the GSA acts once the national media has declared a candidate the winner of the presidential race. Biden is projected to have won the election, with a victory margin exceeding six million votes. He was officially recognized as the victor on November 7 and is scheduled to be sworn into office on January 20.

title: Wikinews interviews Craig Farquharson, Liberal Democrat candidate for 2020 Groom by-election
content:
**Wikinews Interviews Craig Farquharson, Liberal Democrat Candidate for the 2020 Groom By-Election**

Tomorrow, voters in the Australian electorate of Groom are set to head to the polls for a by-election following the resignation of local MP for family reasons. Groom, located in Queensland, centers around the city of Toowoomba. In the last federal election, the Liberal National Party, Queensland's leading conservative party, secured this seat with over 70% of the vote. Since its establishment in 1984, Groom has consistently been held by conservative parties.

Political analysts consider the outcome largely predetermined, with Kevin Bonham labeling it "Australia's most boring by-election" on his blog. However, he emphasized that any significant swing could reflect the general performance of the dominant center-left Labor Party in Queensland, which experienced a 4.2% swing against it in the previous federal election.

Wikinews spoke with one of the four candidates in the by-election, Craig Farquharson, who represents the Liberal Democrats. The party advocates for "individual liberty, free markets, and small government" and currently has two elected officials in the Senate. Farquharson, a former military contractor, owns the King Vapealot vape store in Toowoomba.

**Q: Why are you running to be Groom's local MP?**

**Craig Farquharson:** I decided to run as a candidate for Groom because, as a small business owner, I struggled to get my elected MP to engage with me or even return my calls. This frustration with representatives who are inaccessible motivated me to take action. If elected, I am committed to being as accessible as possible to my constituents.

After 36 years of Groom being a safe seat, residents are ready for change and seek the level of attention that comes with a more marginal electorate — or they want a new party to represent their interests. As a Liberal Democrat, I assure voters in Groom that I can bring them more attention and improve their dealings with the government. Listening to constituents will be my first step towards advocating for a better deal for Groom.

**Q: The Liberal Democrats advocate for small government and reduced regulation. What specific law do you believe needs revision?**

**Craig Farquharson:** We want to eliminate subsidies and allow all technologies to compete on equal footing to lower electricity prices and the cost of living through competition. A significant issue for Groom is overcoming regulatory hurdles, especially in obtaining environmental approvals for local mining operations, which is both a Federal and State concern. 

While Australia can transition to alternative energy sources, many developing nations rely on affordable electricity to combat poverty. By providing high-quality coal, we can make an environmental improvement while addressing global poverty and creating jobs in Groom. This approach would benefit all stakeholders through a sensible reduction of unnecessary regulations.

**Q: As a vape store owner, do you think reforms are needed regarding e-cigarette laws and drug laws overall?**

**Craig Farquharson:** The Liberal Democrats support relaxing certain restrictions to allow individuals to take personal responsibility for their health. We believe that criminalizing recreational drug use is detrimental to society and shifts funds to dangerous criminal enterprises. Drug abuse should be viewed as a health issue rather than a criminal one. We advocate for reforms based on evidence and a scientific approach, rather than punitive measures enforced by unfeeling bureaucrats. Personal health challenges should be addressed by individuals and their healthcare advisors, not by the justice system.

**Q: Why did you decide to join the Liberal Democrats?**

**Craig Farquharson:** The principles of the Liberal Democrats align with my values and those of many small business owners in the electorate, who see themselves as responsible adults capable of making their own decisions.

**Q: The Liberal Democrats have yet to secure a seat in the House of Representatives and have not contested Groom before. What is your goal for this election?**

**Craig Farquharson:** Our goal is to challenge the dominance of the major parties and make a significant impact with our campaign, encouraging a more equitable deal for Groom's residents from the Federal Government. We aim to ensure that the two major parties receive only the proportion of votes they received in the last federal election, while we capture the remaining vote.

**Q: How have COVID-19 restrictions affected your campaign efforts?**

**Craig Farquharson:** In Queensland, very few COVID-19 restrictions have impacted campaigning. Businesses have implemented COVID plans, but these have not limited voter participation or our campaigning efforts. The border closures that separate families and hinder access to healthcare services pose a far greater challenge to the community than our campaign has faced. We empathize with those still experiencing the effects of the pandemic.

**Q: What's a key issue in Groom that requires urgent attention?**

**Craig Farquharson:** Groom has not been a marginal electorate, resulting in insufficient infrastructure funding over the past 36 years under LNP representation. This has left us with significant water, road, and infrastructure issues to resolve. We aim to make Groom a contested seat to ensure that the government is held accountable and to represent the community’s needs. Listening to constituents and local businesses is paramount in my approach, with the principles of the Liberal Democrats guiding my solutions. Most importantly, we need to prioritize the community's voice to secure the necessary support for Groom.

title: Wikinews interviews Sandra Jephcott, Sustainable Australia candidate for 2020 Groom by-election
content:
**Wikinews Interviews Sandra Jephcott, Sustainable Australia Candidate for the 2020 Groom By-election**

Voters in Queensland's Groom electorate are set to head to the polls this week following the resignation of MP by the Liberal National Party for family reasons. Groom, which encompasses the city of Toowoomba, has been a stronghold for conservative parties since its establishment in 1984, with the Liberal National Party winning over 70% of the vote in the last election.

While some political analysts view the by-election as a certainty for the Liberal National Party, Kevin Bonham labeled it "Australia's most boring by-election" on his blog. However, he pointed out that the scale of any swing could reflect the performance of the Labor Party, which suffered a 4.2% decline in Queensland during the last federal election.

Wikinews spoke with Sandra Jephcott, one of four candidates vying for the seat, who is representing the Sustainable Australia Party. According to the party's website, Jephcott is a veterinarian and farmer, holding a veterinary degree from the University of Queensland, along with a Bachelor of Science and a Master of Science from other institutions. In our interview, she shared her views on critical issues including climate change, the COVID-19 pandemic, water security, and foreign ownership of Australian land.

**Q: Why are you running to be Groom's local MP?**

**Sandra Jephcott:** As a veterinarian and farmer living on a 4000-acre property west of Toowoomba, I bring a diverse range of experiences to the role. When Sustainable Australia Party asked me to run to raise awareness for our cause, I was eager to help. I see the Groom by-election as an opportunity for citizens to voice their dissatisfaction with the status quo – particularly regarding rampant political corruption and its detrimental effects on the environment.

**Q: You’ve stated your desire to tackle climate change. What’s your plan?**

**Sandra Jephcott:** There’s no single solution to climate change. The Sustainable Australia Party has a comprehensive plan, which includes:
- Funding and subsidizing renewable energy research and energy efficiency initiatives.
- Committing to net zero or negative emissions by 2050, or ideally sooner.
- Enacting a moratorium on new coal mines and major coal mine expansions.
- Implementing a ban on new coal-fired power stations.
- Phasing out fossil fuel subsidies.
- Establishing a fair carbon pricing mechanism.
- Promoting the benefits of plant-based diets.
- Addressing population growth pressures.

**Q: What actions do you believe are necessary in Toowoomba for environmental and water protection?**

**Sandra Jephcott:** Despite hosting an annual Carnival of Flowers, Toowoomba faces challenges in residents' access to green spaces. It’s essential to protect and expand areas in and around Toowoomba to prevent housing sprawl that harms tree canopies and green spaces. Water management is critical; we need to reduce waste, expand water tank usage, and explore recycled water options. Long-term water security for Toowoomba is also contingent upon decisive action on climate change.

**Q: What are your thoughts on the federal government's COVID-19 response?**

**Sandra Jephcott:** Overall, the Morrison Government's response has been prudent, despite initial hesitance to prioritize health over economic growth. However, there were significant gaps in support for vulnerable workers and industries, like casual workers and the arts, who faced inadequate assistance during the pandemic.

**Q: Why did you choose to join Sustainable Australia?**

**Sandra Jephcott:** My science background played a significant role in my decision. It was critical for me that Sustainable Australia Party follows a science-based approach to policy. I believe they are the only party offering a holistic plan addressing environmental issues, with emphasis on strong climate action and stabilizing population growth both domestically and globally.

**Q: Why is foreign ownership of farms and land an important issue?**

**Sandra Jephcott:** As a sovereign nation, it’s crucial for Australia to manage its natural resources sustainably and ensure that profits, jobs, and tax revenue benefit Australians. Selling off our resources undermines our ability to fulfill vital economic, environmental, and social objectives.

**Q: How have COVID-19 restrictions impacted your campaign efforts?**

**Sandra Jephcott:** I've been able to work at early voting centers and conduct media interviews without significant restrictions, which has allowed me to campaign effectively.

**Q: What’s one key issue in Groom that requires immediate attention?**

**Sandra Jephcott:** The Sustainable Australia Party prioritizes three main issues in this by-election: protecting our environment, curtailing overdevelopment, and combating corruption. Our foremost priority is environmental protection, which includes vigorous action on climate change. Unlike the other candidates, only the Sustainable Australia Party advocates for a moratorium on new coal mines and major expansions, such as the proposed New Acland Mine expansion.

title: US professional wrestler Jon Huber dies aged 41
content:
US professional wrestler Jon Huber, known in WWE as Luke Harper and in All Elite Wrestling (AEW) as Brodie Lee, passed away on Saturday at the age of 41.

Huber's wife, Amanda, revealed that he succumbed to an unspecified lung disorder, which was not related to COVID-19, after receiving treatment. At the time of his passing, Huber was under contract with AEW but had been absent from television tapings since October for undisclosed reasons. The wrestling community has reacted with shock and sorrow to the news of his death.

"Heartbroken and numb," wrote Huber's longtime tag team partner on social media. "I have lost not only a friend but a brother!"

During his WWE tenure from 2012 to 2019, Huber, an imposing six-foot-five figure, was part of the faction known as The Wyatt Family alongside Rowan. He captured the WWE Tag Team Championship once and the Intercontinental Championship. After requesting his release from WWE, Huber joined AEW at the beginning of this year. He made his debut in March as Brodie Lee, the leader of the villainous faction The Dark Order. This past August, he secured the AEW TNT Championship.

An AEW press release paid tribute to Huber, stating, "Jon was exceptionally respected and loved in every way, a fierce and captivating talent, a thoughtful mentor, and simply a very kind soul that starkly contradicted his persona as Mr. Brodie Lee. His love for his wife Amanda and children Brodie and Nolan was evident to all of us who were fortunate enough to spend time with him."

WWE expressed its condolences to Huber's family, friends, and fans, and has featured a video on their website celebrating his career.
